review: [A] funny, inventive, scary film.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: That their cast of non-professionals and unknowns represents immigrants, minorities and the disabled in such a unifying and uplifting work is all the more reason to embrace an independent film that just might restore your faith in humanity.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: As sharp as it is blunt, Give Me Liberty is a bravura piece of filmmaking. Although it's not always successful, it delivers a swift kick to an industry that has sidelined characters like these for far too long.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: Give Me Liberty's biggest victory is in avoiding depicting able-bodied driver Vic [Chris Galust] as the shining knight-in-armor savior, or sacrifice the other actors as props to inspire able-bodied audiences

title: Give Me Liberty
review: It's the perspective of a thoroughly acculturated Russian immigrant who has nothing in life but his work and a crate of old vinyl.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: In his first foray into filmmaking, Mikhanovsky exhibits a strong sense for personal connection and certainly plenty of ambition in his style.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: [W]hen co-writer/director Mikhanovsky tries to imbue his ... story with more significance ... the filmmaker loses track of what makes his movie significant in the first place.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: "Give Me Liberty" is a must-see. Take some friends. Spread the word.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: It's a ride that opens the door to a diverse and important community. With wonderfully raw and absorbing performances, this small tale is a rare treat.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: A funny and charming indie with good performances by the non-professional cast.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: Mikhanosvky turns his camera on communities that are frequently marginalized in both film and in American society. Immigrants and people with disabilities are often ignored, rarely protagonists in films unless portrayed by a famous actor.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: Deep down, we're all in the same boat - or the same van.

title: Give Me Liberty
review: As the day deteriorates from erratic to near-disastrous, the collective ride shared between this inclusive cast of characters becomes not only a pleasantly-delivered dramatic and comedic experience, but a damn-near, compassionate one as well.
A series of disconnected scenes, rather than a narrative with a sense of momentum.
Though the title would have you believe you were watching a "futuristic" film involving robots, the truth is, it just feels like a cheesy soap opera or novella.
To simply dismiss it because of surface notions is to ignore the slippery slope of where we are going as a population ruled by new technological advancements everyday.

2050 is ostensibly a film about sex robots, hand-crafted by Dean Cain. But really, it's just a movie about terrible people rationalizing terrible behaviors in the most verbose, unnatural ways possible.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: We are seeing the world - in all its sadness and beauty - through his eyes. Banderas brings it all to life.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: As slow and meandering as the film feels at times, DP José Luis Alcaine's eye is a constant that enlivens the screen when the narrative struggles to.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: Courtesy of Almodóvar's masterful direction and a career-finest performance from Banderas, we feel every moment with Salvador. The pain, the glory, and everything in-between.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: I love seeing Banderas directed by Almodóvar, especially in this role which is obviously a stand-in for the director himself. He uneasily occupies the screen, clearly trying to manage both his pain and his loved ones' response to it.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: This certainly feels like we know much more about the film's creator than from any of his (Almodóvar) other films.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: Tonally, this is nothing new for Almodóvar, but there's something truly special about the groove he finds with Banderas.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: From his time in the wilderness, Almodóvar has emerged with a stunner. Heavily introspective, Pain and Glory is about aging and finding a reason to go on when your body fails and inspiration is lacking.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: Its strands of fictionalized memoir work decently, but it's its more insightful look at religion and art throughout childhood that bring something to the table.

title: Pain and Glory (Dolor y gloria)
review: Pedro Almodóvar's latest film is a masterpiece that balances the personal with the relatable.

title: The Corrupted
review: It's a better than decent thriller that you can catch on your telly.

title: The Corrupted
review: A well-written, well-acted and hard-hitting piece of material accompanied by an excellent musical score. And it features Timothy Spall and Hugh Bonneville in key roles as some of the villains indicated in the movie's title.

title: The Corrupted
review: Wastes its cast and intriguing potential with a cliche by the numbers gangster film that lacks energy or engaging suspense.

title: The Corrupted

title: The Corrupted
review: Saddled with a convoluted plot.

title: The Corrupted
review: Violent, profane, but entertaining British gangster movie.

title: The Corrupted
review: The efforts of some talented actors are squandered in this by-the-numbers British crime thriller.

title: The Corrupted

title: Mine 9

title: Mine 9
review: The results aren't golden, but this mine strikes a solid vein of silver with its subterranean drama.

title: Mine 9
review: Mine 9 is the most poignant and terrifying sort of drama: a film about good, hard working, sympathetic people in a life or death situation.

title: Mine 9
review: An indie film about a team of Appalachian coal miners trapped two miles down, trying to crawl their way up with an hour of oxygen, Mine 9 makes maximum use of the dark in all its frightening implications.

title: Mine 9

title: Mine 9
review: A satisfyingly intense and efficiently filmed bit of counterprogramming for those suffering from superhero fatigue.

title: Mine 9
review: Mensore does his due diligence in showing us the claustrophobic, perilous conditions of the mine, even before disaster strikes...

title: Mine 9
review: ...here's a film about something real, not a horror picture about a group of shapely cavers who descend into the earth and get trapped with monsters chasing them. The monsters in the effective, streamlined thriller "Mine 9" are all around us.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: A fascinating if sometimes repetitive account of an emotionally abusive relationship between mother and son. The outdoor scenes that reference Lowry's paintings lighten the claustrophobia.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Timothy Spall's performance is a sterling study of understatement and pent-up frustration opposite a bed-bound Venessa Redgrave, who plays his domineering, ego-crushing horror of a mother.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: ...has a small canvas (sorry), and it suffers from a certain determined ordinariness, but it is affecting in other ways.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: On the screen, Mrs Lowry and Son, much like one of Lowry's own paintings, is a wee gem on a small canvas, full of loving details within its apparently simple and unadorned style.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: An essay on family, and life, by two of the greatest living actors.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Vanessa Redgrave and Timothy Spall give a master class in acting. The whole movie is a character study but what a study it is in the hands of these terrific thespians.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Biopic about artist's relationship with his bullying mother.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Mrs Lowry & Son ... is stuck in the mire of the worst aspects of their relationship and the monotonous narrative.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Mrs. Lowry And Son is by turns hilarious, brutal and tender, and like the best drama, it will leave you wondering what's going on behind the closed doors of all the other houses in Pendlebury and further afield.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: Mrs. Lowry and Son has an appealing old-school charm and two performances that make it worth seeing.

title: Mrs. Lowry & Son
review: A study of the painter LS Lowry that, with sly whimsy and darkness, finds a universality of the creative psyche via the toxic relationship with his mother, who tried (unsuccessfully) to crush him.

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes
review: ...we lose just a little too much momentum.

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes

title: The Two Popes
review: The magic of this mostly fictional film from Netflix is that it imagines an example of authentic listening and dialogue.

title: The Two Popes
review: The Two Popes is a wonderful showcase of great acting (both the leads are phenomenal), brilliant casting, effective writing, and terrific cinematography.

title: Imprisoned

title: Imprisoned

title: Jexi

title: Jexi

title: Jexi
review: Adam Devine is more enjoyable in small doses - like supporting roles and not leading the charge. Michael Pena, we feel your pain. Come back, all is forgiven - this, Dora, everything!

title: Jexi
review: Spends its time doing all of the tedious, schlocky things that romcoms do, only it does them with a laborious "extremely online" twist.

title: Jexi
review: If you want to make a movie with some regressive, oft-repeated views on technology, at least commit to the bit. Otherwise, don't bother.

title: Dark Encounter (Transience)

review: Come for the devil's music, stay for Rutger Hauer haunting the screen from beyond.

title: The Sonata
review: An underwhelming gothic horror film that's too low on palpable scares and suspense.

title: The Sonata

title: The Sonata

title: The Sonata
review: A film that hits some of the right notes without coming together as a fully realized piece.

title: The Sonata
review: While the director clearly has a few tricks up his sleeve for hitting his viewers with the heebie jeebies, what he doesn't have, at least for The Sonata, is a sense of how to weave those tricks into a unified, cohesive narrative.

review: All of this is so light ... that it threatens to float away... It's so pleasant, though, that the familiarity hardly matters.

title: Countdown

title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch

title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch

review: It's not tongue-in-cheek; it means everything it puts out there, but it makes sure the audience knows how absurd it is because children are absurd-genuinely, sincerely, seriously absurd. They're weird and deep and dark, and this is the show they deserve.

title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
review: This colorful show takes a new approach to sketch comedy that falls flat in the areas of delivery, humor and cohesion.

title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch

title: John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch
review: John Mulaney & the Sack Lunch Bunch excels at amplifying those weird moments of pre-adolescence, when you're trying to assert yourself more but aren't always taken seriously because you're "just a kid."

review: Mulaney's in total control, and yet completely out of his element.

title: Melody Makers

title: Melody Makers
review: While it's technically dry and straightforward, the film finds an agreeably nostalgic rhythm.

title: Melody Makers

title: Melody Makers
review: It's always engaging and professionally designed in terms of the overall content, but it also feels at times like a shorter film that has been padded out to feature length.

title: Melody Makers
review: Leslie Ann Coles' feature debut chronicles the magazine's heyday in the '60s and '70s; if Melody Maker had been a band, this was the period when it went electric.

title: Melody Makers
review: The entire documentary plays like a trailer for itself, speeding through everything so quickly as though it's afraid we'll get bored and change the channel.

title: Welcome To Curiosity

title: Welcome To Curiosity
review: The dialogue is awful, the characters are paper-thin, the acting is atrocious and the pacing laborious.

title: Welcome To Curiosity
review: Each actor struggles with the corny dialog, especially speeches that strain to sound vaguely Tarantino-esque.

title: 6 Underground
review: In the moments that connect the action, 6 Underground becomes one of the worst, most cringeworthy movies of the last few years.

title: 6 Underground
review: A scattered grab bag of images and noises.

title: 6 Underground

title: 6 Underground
review: It's not clever. It's not classy. He thinks it is. But it's bold and tough, and you will respect the awesome might of military technology, else be visited in the night by wicked-rad army ninjas in stealth Blackhawks...

title: 6 Underground
review: This is indeed a Michael Bay movie, and it has no shame about that. It's utterly insane-and an absolute blast.

title: 6 Underground
review: This is about as optional as it gets...it's not taking up big screens for "real cinema," but it's just there for people who know they enjoy this type of thing. It's very transparent.

title: 6 Underground
review: I'm not a Michael Bay fan, but despite myself, I was really enjoying this. A guilty pleasure.

title: 6 Underground
review: Netflix's sorry attempt at building an action franchise goes very awry with a project that has absolutely no redeeming qualities.

title: 6 Underground
review: It's so over-the-top that it's oddly dull.

title: 6 Underground
review: Reynolds has clearly been hired to deliver Deadpool-esque deadpan, which he does with aplomb.

title: 6 Underground
review: The result is an absurd orgy of action and comedy with no filter whatsoever. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: 6 Underground
review: Military idolatry and craven female objectification and a belief that the rich will save us? 6 Underground has it all!

title: Joker
review: What cannot be argued is that Phoenix has once again turned in an Oscar-worthy performance...

title: Joker
review: A movie that borders on genius-repellant, dark, terrifying, disgusting, brilliant and unforgettable.

title: Joker
review: If there is a meaningful difference between performing and acting, Joaquin Phoenix surely exemplifies the former here, creepily contorting as the Clown Prince of Crime in Todd Phillips' timely, toxic take on the Making of a Murdering Madman.

title: Joker
review: While it succeeds in aping the superficial aspects of [Martin] Scorsese's style, "Joker" lacks the intelligence or gravitas of Scorsese's best work.

title: Joker
review: A movie of a cynicism so vast and pervasive as to render the viewing experience even emptier than its slapdash aesthetic does.

title: Joker
review: Bleak and juvenile

title: Joker
review: It's disingenuous and pandering for Phillips to root through a grab bag of resentments and pick out only the least problematic, like he's trying to find the last candy in the bag that isn't licorice.

title: Joker
review: JOKER is a beautiful but simplistically shallow tale of one man's downward spiral, tacked on to a recognisable cinematic icon. Todd Phillips's film is a Batmobile with the engine of a clown car.

title: Joker
review: The more I watched it, the more I disliked it. Just did not work for me, I hate this movie.

title: Joker
review: The whole damn thing is directed with such boldness and vision that Todd Phillips (yeah, the Hangover guy) should never look back again. A big-screen must see.

title: Joker
review: Not only an intelligent throwback to the feel-bad shock cinema of the 1970s, Joker is all but unique in its social realism...

title: Joker
review: Cinema is dead. Here is your proof.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: A truly original directorial vision brought to life with visual flair and narrative verve.

title: Daniel Isn't Real

title: Daniel Isn't Real

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: Daniel Isn't Real is a psychological trip that you feel genre cinema has taken before but there are enough stylistic flurries and touches here to make it a memorable film and one that only benefits from repeated viewings.

title: Daniel Isn't Real

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: Like Donnie Darko Raising Cain for a Fight Club up Jacob's Ladder, this mind frying, retina searing, penal gland pickling cult in the making should be sought out and seen on as big a screen as possible to be believed and best appreciated.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: Stylistically sophisticated and psychologically insightful, this is an exquisitely ambiguous and inventively disturbing mashup of body horror, demonic possession, and Lovecraftian science fiction.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: It's all an exercise in style over substance.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: There are a lot of ideas here and there's a lot of strong material, so one can forgive the borrowings and clichés to a degree.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: Robbins and Schwarzenegger are both excellent, feeding and bouncing off of each other like an actual real-life toxic friendship.

title: Daniel Isn't Real
review: Whether this is your cup of tea or not, one must admire DeLeeuw for the mystic-induced creativity and Mortimer for the capably execution.

title: A Million Little Pieces

title: A Million Little Pieces

title: A Million Little Pieces

title: A Million Little Pieces

title: A Million Little Pieces
review: This is a journey, troubling and perhaps dangerous but well-worth taking.

title: A Million Little Pieces

title: A Million Little Pieces
review: Adults-only rehab drama shocks but falls short on story.

title: A Million Little Pieces
review: [The filmmakers are] bound to [its] shortcomings because the text's drama is born solely from James' fear while everyone [else] distracts from the redundancy of that truth.

title: A Million Little Pieces
review: A million little melodrama rehab cliches.

review: A sober portrait about rehabilitation that's more stimulating in the conversation of what it shows and leaves out. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: Dolan's most conventional film, and consequently the dullest. [Full review in French]

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: Even for someone like me who admires Dolan, the finished film is a bit of a mess. But it's kind of a beautiful mess, one that still has the power to be affecting.

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: The three-story narrative is the film's biggest misstep, by giving short shrift to what should have been the whole point of the film - the titular "death and life" of the main character.

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: A film with a fair bit to like within its shaggy, unwieldy construction, but not enough to outweigh the fact that Dolan's latest is an unqualified mess.

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: As flawed as it is, the film occasionally shines through its gloomy atmosphere with an attempt at defining the unfair cost of passion.

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: The hottest mess at #TIFF18.

title: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan
review: What this needs is cohesion and a greater insight into the actions and outcomes he traces. And, most importantly, it needs far more heart than what is ultimately there. A Dolan film without the heart is about as disappointing as you can get.

title: In Fabric
review: ...a beautifully realised film that engages with the true potentials of contemporary cinema.

title: In Fabric

title: In Fabric

title: In Fabric
review: With such a promising premise that could have been strange but alluring, you're left with a confused and irritating feeling that nothing really made sense.

title: In Fabric

title: In Fabric

title: In Fabric

title: In Fabric
review: It feels so tantalizingly close to a perfect, atmospheric film...Still, fans of Strickland's work will continue to find a lot to love here.

title: In Fabric
review: It doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but Peter Strickland's hallucinatory horror-comedy looks and sounds like no other genre film in recent memory.

title: In Fabric
review: I found it wildly original.

title: In Fabric
review: "In Fabric" is a unique experience best taken in with logic left at the door.

title: In Fabric
review: For giallo fans in particular, the surreally voyeuristic experience of In Fabric is visually engrossing and unshakably uncomfortable.

title: To Kid or Not to Kid

title: To Kid or Not to Kid

title: To Kid or Not to Kid

title: To Kid or Not to Kid
review: Gently witty, perceptive and convincingly introspective, Kid stands in its truth about a different kind of mantle for perceived womanhood.

title: To Kid or Not to Kid

title: To Kid or Not to Kid
review: An engaging personal essay documentary about not having children, complete with interviews, arguments, hard data and sound reasoning coming from both sides of the debate

title: To Kid or Not to Kid
review: Strong arguments hold that having children is in some cases a selfish choice. Not having children, by contrast, is not selfish.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: While Barbara Rubin and the Exploding NY Underground isn't for everyone, Smith's documentary is worth a look for any fans of the New York counterculture movement.

review: As close as we're likely to get to a genuine biography of one of cinema's most elusive artists.

review: In Chuck Smith's bittersweet profile, critics, filmmakers, and friends pay testament to Rubin's talent, energy, and startling lack of inhibition.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: Reanimates the young Jewish woman who challenged men's alt-culture...with her vulva images, charisma, and artistic matchmaking...Imperfectly integrates her disparate lives.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: It may be much too short, but pound for pound, minute for minute, there are few biographical documentaries more impressive than this.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: Perhaps one day film will indeed change the world for the better, but for now, all we can do is watch and experience what's left of the experimental media of that time and wistfully remind ourselves of what we missed.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: A story about a unique personality who personified the toll that living in the avant-garde took.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: A fascinating portrait of a "larger than life" filmmaker and collaborator.

title: Barbara Rubin & the Exploding NY Underground
review: A worthy introduction to a lesser known filmmaker. Well-edited and illuminating. A must-see for film buffs.

title: Judy

title: Judy

title: Judy
review: Zellweger's womanlike skill is strikingly admirable but the passion of Judy Garland just didn't zing the strings of my heart.

title: Judy

title: Judy

title: Judy

title: Judy

review: Despite the production's shortcomings, it's an uncomfortable watch and tragic because this isn't just Judy Garland's story but an example of Hollywood repeating itself.

review: A bomb that achieves the feat of being a hagiography that makes the protagonist unbearable.

title: Judy
review: As a biopic, it is not extraordinary and it verges on cheesy more than once, but watch it to see what all the fuss over Zellweger is about.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: If you've ever found yourself wondering how American politics attained its current level of crazed amorality, Where's My Roy Cohn? provides a few answers.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: A brisk and interesting synopsis of man whose dogged pursuit of fame and power corroded any trace of personal morality.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: The film suffers to some extent from having such an unsympathetic subject - and the attempts to humanise him only serve to make his actual behaviour seem venaler. It is, however, timely enough, and fascinating in a reptilian kind of way.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: Lawyer Cohn apparently pulled many malicious stunts in his life. Now director Tyrnauer, whose sex swipes at dead movie stars in his last documentary somehow seemed credible, delivers a real hitjob that remains more absorbing than on point.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: The film delivers high-speed tabloid journalism and rolls along swiftly. It's jammed with information that make shock the unknowing.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: This is a film that is a study in power and how one man shaped political discourse in ways that no one saw before, but has been elevated to new levels today.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: Prosecutorial as it is, Matt Tyrnauer shows us the weirdly whimsical side of the man... I guess even river scum must have professional courtesy.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: Roy Cohn is dead, but as Where's My Roy Cohn? makes dismayingly clear is that his ghost still haunts us.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: Where's My Roy Cohn? could be a soap opera if it wasn't so real.

title: Where's My Roy Cohn?
review: ... succeeds by digging deeper into Cohn's personal life and his public image, showing how a shadowy figure like Cohn gains influence and wields power behind the scenes, and persuasively connects his legacy to present-day affairs.

title: Knives and Skin
review: I'll be spending a lifetime with Knives and Skin. It is a beautiful revelation that we are all whole and never alone.

title: Knives and Skin
review: Knives and Skin is also a deeply feminist film, which embraces all parts of the female experience, and features a woman-driven story.

title: Knives and Skin
review: What's most frustrating aboutKnives and Skinis despite all of these wild and weird ingredients, there is simply no connective tissue to keep everything together. Reeder's vision is frustratingly opaque.

title: Knives and Skin
review: It's ambitious, very ambitious, in juggling a wide range of characters on a very limited budget...it didn't speak to me but I invite everyone to see for themselves...

title: Knives and Skin
review: There's a lot to process here. Perhaps the writer-director should have tried, you know, processing it.

title: Knives and Skin
review: Unfortunately all the neon-lit cinematography and woozy score from Nick Zinner can't make up for how tired and affected this film's off-kilter tone feels.

title: Knives and Skin
review: Everything is odd in the world of this film but, with very few exceptions, it all feels as if it was heaped on in order to make the relatively dull central story marginally more interesting and colorful.

title: Knives and Skin
review: A movie as strange as this one needs some grounding in reality. Knives and Skin gives us some -- but not nearly enough.

title: Knives and Skin

title: Knives and Skin
review: To Reeder's immense credit, her film glides forward with an aura of mystery but never feels like genre mix-and-match.

title: Knives and Skin
review: Like a fractured fairy tale, this luridly coloured film mixes horror, black comedy and mystery, like a pink-washed Twin Peaks

title: Knives and Skin

title: Piranhas (La paranza dei bambini)

title: Piranhas (La paranza dei bambini)

title: Piranhas (La paranza dei bambini)
review: Eternal violence.

review: Despite Giovannesi's fine eye for detail and Di Napoli's impressive screen debut, Piranhas never quite reaches the heights of Gomorrah, Dogman, or Reality, to name three outstanding examples of the current wave of Naples crime pics.

review: The scrappy filmmaking and petty criminal antics fit the scale of this Gomorrah Jr.

review: It flashes potential on both sides of the camera, but this gritty Italian crime thriller is conventional beneath its mildly unsettling surface.

title: Piranhas (La paranza dei bambini)
review: Much of what transpires in [Claudio] Giovannesi's mob-mashup feels a trifle old hat, even its unblinking rawness.

title: Piranhas (La paranza dei bambini)
review: To be certain, it crackles and sparks at points, but it never catches fire.

title: I See You

title: I See You

title: I See You
review: A stylish, twisty and eerie crime thriller.

title: I See You
review: I See You takes chances that I wish more films of this budget and style would take. It never lets you quite settle into what you think it is or isn't going to be.

title: I See You
review: From clichéd plot devices to the somber score, what starts off feeling amateurish and tiresome becomes a crafty nailbiter.

title: I See You
review: I See You is an impressive exercise in precision plotting.

title: I See You
review: What's said about hiding in plain sight cannot be understated, which may be the film's scariest message of all.

title: I See You
review: ... steers its story in multiple directions with mixed results, although even when its central mystery becomes muddled, the film maintains a suspenseful undercurrent.

title: I See You
review: Screenwriter Devon Graye has created a smartly written storyline that plays with the tropes of a number of familiar genres in interesting ways that keep viewers guessing.

title: I See You
review: I See You never finds a solid foundation for its story.

title: I See You
review: A trick, but a pretty good one....may be a mite too clever for its own good, but you have to admire the chutzpah involved.

title: I See You
review: Reveals are either preposterous or disappointing, leaving the audience with hope that yet another trick is being planned to get a feature that often derails back on track.

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: A film I enjoyed far more than I thought I would.

title: Lucy in the Sky

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: Without a doubt, Hawley is one to watch. He's one of the most visually daring directors working at the moment. But here, the material runs away with him.

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: Portman gives her all, but she out-classes this rather pedestrian telling of a story of stratospheric levels of obsession and ambition.

title: Lucy in the Sky

title: Lucy in the Sky

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: A flimsy, effortful project that simply has no footing either as fact or convincing fiction. It's in freefall from the word go.

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: [Natalie] Portman has a great track record of playing women under extreme psychological pressure and this turn is equally Oscar-worthy. Unfortunately, the film supporting her, over-directed by TV's Noah Hawley, isn't of the same calibre.

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: I call these "sadstronaut" movies.

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: Filmmaker Noah Hawley delivers a slow-moving and mostly underwhelming character study that persistently holds the viewer at arms length...

title: Lucy in the Sky
review: Lucy in the Sky wastes Natalie Portman in a film that fails to grasp that not every story about women is one of empowerment.

title: 2 in the Bush: A Love Story

title: 2 in the Bush: A Love Story
review: With proud maturity and still plenty of passion, Two in the Bush presents an honest tale of such a three-wheeled romance.

title: 2 in the Bush: A Love Story
review: While the concept is all too often lost in love stories on screen, Two in the Bush: A Love Story puts the polyamorous relationship front and center.

title: 2 in the Bush: A Love Story
review: Two in the Bush mixes comedy with deeply emotional moments. The result is highly relatable content which one can identify with whilst laughing at how ridiculous humans can be, specifically when dealing with love.

title: 2 in the Bush: A Love Story
review: This sensitive and restrained portrait of a polyamorous relationship is admirable for giving more attention to Emily's journey as an individual than her place in romantic unions.

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)
review: An uneven piece about 'trigger issues' in one man's professional and personal lives, but the strengths outweigh the weaknesses, if only by a slight margin.

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)
review: There's a level of sincerity to After Class that almost makes its narrative messiness worthwhile.

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)
review: Schechter provides a lived-in vibe for the effort, collecting strong performances and enough relatable behavioral challenges to secure a compelling foray into the abyss of human fallibility.

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)
review: The Messiest Dramedy of the Year...still a fun mess to watch, and a fine showcase for Justin Long.

title: After Class (Safe Spaces)
review: A perfect showcase for Justin Long.

title: Ice on Fire

title: Marriage Story
review: Baumbach's approach to the challenge of representing marriage and divorce is to treat both as absurdities. His film, though heavy and at times heart-wrenching, leans heavily into comedy -- self-deprecating and humiliating at times, but no less funny.

title: Marriage Story
review: Baumbach approximates it well, but never quite achieves Bergman's mastery of interior drama.

title: Marriage Story
review: An endearing and extremely dramatic "love gone awry" story that feels very relevant to today's disconnected society. [Full review in Spanish].

title: Marriage Story
review: The film captures a palpable love gone awry with a young boy caught in the crossfire. It's a telling, emotionally devastating, yet somehow cathartic work.

title: Marriage Story
review: Baumbach is an expert farceur.

title: Marriage Story
review: "Cries easily in movies..." wholly and accurately describes my own experience watching this film.

title: Marriage Story
review: It's wise and emotionally battering, but it never forgets to be crazily funny and doesn't pander. Beautiful, heartbreaking stuff.

title: Marriage Story
review: Jennifer Jason Leigh will never watch this movie, and neither should she.

title: Marriage Story

title: Marriage Story
review: Marriage Story follows the confusion and mounting frustrations of Charlie, while Nicole's motivations feel largely opaque.

title: Marriage Story
review: Probably should have been called Divorce Story, but that wouldn't look as welcoming on the marquee!

title: Marriage Story
review: What is so startling is Nicole and Charlie's lack of depth about their lives. Yes, they mourn the end of their marriage, but Baumbach's script offers no emotional or spiritual rationale for their sorrow.

title: The Two Popes

review: Pryce and Hopkins ensure we can mostly see past the issues and enjoy a tale that might well be, it must be said, three-quarters-or-so fictional.

review: Meirelles has reformed the historical drama in a way that makes going to church entertaining. The Two Popes is a blessing to us all.

review: What we are witnessing is an open process that... This film is part of that process. And this is the interesting thing. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Rabid

review: Vandervoort does her best to give Rose more depth than the script offers, but it's an uphill battle.

title: Rabid

title: Rabid

title: Rabid
review: Outlandish fun, with lashings of gore and extravagantly disgusting practical effects compensating for the ripe dialogue and Mackenzie Gray's camped-out performance.

title: Rabid
review: A crummy, distressingly slapdash remake, one that's especially disappointing coming from the Soskas.

title: Rabid
review: It's lesser Cronenberg, but with a better lead actress.

title: Rabid
review: It's possible this remake could grow on me when I take the time to watch it again. Here's hoping that ends up being the case.

title: Rabid
review: The Soska sisters' en vogue approach opens the door for reinvention, but fumbles what Cronenberg was able to accomplish when intensifying society's already contagious disease.

review: Although competently made from a technical perspective, the movie is unexpectedly bland on a story level.

title: The Cotton Club Encore

title: The Cotton Club Encore
review: Encore is a social-consciousness musical, brought back to challenge an era in which social consciousness itself isn't enough.

title: The Cotton Club Encore
review: Gorgeously shot, art directed and costumed, the visuals were strong but the storytelling was not clear. Filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola has released a 139-minute director's cut, and his revisions finally do justice to the script.

title: Mob Town

title: Mob Town
review: A quick Google search will provide more historical insight than the screenplay, which is hampered by wooden dialogue and narrative clichés. Worse, it looks as cheap as it sounds.

title: Mob Town

review: So much can be said about Mob Town and none of it is good.

review: Make it a comedy, make it about the catering, make it more an "Analyze This" sort of mob movie, then you've got something.

review: A fascinating, if heartless, failure, skimming the surface of the conspiracy, not doing justice to the tragedy.

review: Don't expect to be rewarded for making it to the end because the luck and charm that carried the first film to stardom are nowhere to be found by the time the credits roll.

review: The weakest entry in the series feels like it's running on autopilot and introduces some problematic new elements of the mythos.

title: A Christmas Prince: The Royal Baby
review: The Royal Baby is a hilarious, so-bad-it's-good (well maybe not good, but definitely entertaining)...

review: More than any previous Netflix Christmas film, A Christmas Prince: The Royal Baby is pure escapism.

review: After two duds in a row, this franchise is cursed.

review: Every scene in A Christmas Prince 3 that's not in the trailer feels like it was put there simply to pad out the empty space; every attempt at banter or jokes is partnered with a chuckle-heavy pause that drags for five seconds too long.

title: Code 8

title: Code 8
review: Either way, it's a lot of future to absorb in 98 minutes. But in the spirit of the movie I say: More powers to him.

title: Code 8
review: An investment that definitely paid off, Code 8 is a thrill a minute must-see that delivers a fresh take on superpowers and features a scene-stealing performance from Robbie Amell.

title: Most Likely to Succeed

title: Most Likely to Succeed
review: I believe the filmmakers thought there would be more to it when they began their endeavor. This is what they got. Sadly, come award season, this doc is not most likely to succeed.

title: Most Likely to Succeed
review: Ambitious, smart and affecting documentary that follows four disparatehigh school over-achievers ten years past graduation.

title: Hell on the Border

title: Hell on the Border
review: Gyasi's quiet gravitas and the excellent supporting cast bring an engaging story to life.

review: Reduces Reeves to a cheap action-movie stereotype, just another generic Western lawman gunning down anonymous henchmen in cowboy hats.

review: Legendary frontier marshal Bass Reeves gets a shoddy western. Hell on the Border shines a spotlight on the lawman, but fails in almost every other regard.

title: Michelle Wolf: Joke Show

review: Stream it.

title: Michelle Wolf: Joke Show
review: When you're as funny as [Michelle] Wolf, you don't need to distract from your hilarious-and occasionally disturbing-stand-up.

title: The Great War
review: Lobs more cinema war cliches than grenades.

review: Mostly recycled war movie cliches, with the props - guns, explosions, etc. - occasionally giving away the paltry budget.

title: The Irishman

title: The Irishman
review: One of Scorsese's masterworks.

title: The Irishman
review: This is a magnificently wise, majestic, top-shelf work about the relentless passage of time and the fate awaiting us all, connected or not.

title: The Irishman
review: Stephen Zaillian's script tells a mob story we've seen many times before.

title: The Irishman
review: Maybe somewhere along the way, over the course of careers as long as Frank Sheeran's and longer than I've been alive, these guys have earned their self-indulgence

title: The Irishman
review: ...This is a gargantuan piece of cinema that would be a fitting conclusion to the master filmmaker's career if he was ready to stop here.

review: This is a well-made movie by a truly great director and the acting is fine, but the story seems kind of pointless. There is a lot of killing, a lot of suffering, and for what? On the other hand, maybe that is the point of it after all.

title: Olivia (The Pit of Loneliness)

review: Director Audry and her sister, screenwriter Colette Audry, made Olivia as artists, not activists. And the cast of exquisitely nuanced actresses exercised imaginative understatement.

title: Olivia (The Pit of Loneliness)
review: Olivia is an entertainingly scripted scenario of repressed lust, exemplified in every possibly way, but quite brilliantly through a script filled with observational bon mots.

title: Freetown

review: Draggy and one-note, [Freetown is] an indie more interested in reaffirming Mormon dogma than in delivering compelling drama.

review: A dawdling, flat account of African missionaries on the run from rebels that takes forever to get going and even longer to arrive.

title: Abominable

review: Family doesn't have to mean father, mother, children and in-laws, sometimes there are missing people, so friends take up the slack, and even animals can be family members, especially large, white, furry ones. Abominable is fun entertainment.

review: Pitt mentions in the film that his journey has covered 2 billion miles. Believe me, it feels like you were along for every last one.

review: Chapter Two struggles to maintain a taut narrative and its scares end up feeling repetitive.

review: A long plod through Tarantino's reflections on Hollywood in 1969 that are summed up pretty well by the shrug emoji.

review: Still, this imperfect Hollywood fairy tale is largely enjoyable with many memorable elements and is ultimately essential viewing for movie fans.

review: Tarantino deliciously and elegantly comments on the town's contradictions and double standards, while also taking the time to build up his two lead characters in relatable, convincing ways.

review: This is one piece of heritage that's better forgotten.

review: Despite an intriguing premise, this film goes absolutely nowhere, opting for random gore as opposed to containing any real ideas.

title: Portals
review: The cohesion and payoff I was awaiting wasn't coming. Sigh.

title: Portals
review: Portals ensures connective tissue unites worldwide events within each localized story, but loses the inherent variety of anthology freedoms in doing so.

title: Portals
review: A sci-fi/horror anthology that tries to tighten the format, but still suffers the usual pace, flow and suspense problems of film anthologies.

title: Portals
review: There's no character progression, nothing is explained, yet the audience is assaulted with a ton of pointless exposition, wooden acting, and a hilarious ending that's supposed to be tantalizingly ambiguous but instead reeks of desperation.

title: Portals
review: A poorly structured, forgettable horror anthology that leaves a lot to be desired.

title: The Gallows Act II
review: The Gallows Act II is aggressively awful. The filmmaking quality barely meets direct-to-video standard, and despite a lead actress who really tries, the movie does not respect her character or any other character in the story.

title: The Gallows Act II
review: You just cannot help but think that they thought it was a good idea at the time, started rolling and realised it was too late to rethink

title: The Gallows Act II
review: Marginally better than its found-footage predecessor, which isn't saying much, this horror sequel still falls prey to the usual clichés, from cheap jump scares to not-very-smart characters.

title: The Gallows Act II
review: The Gallows Act II is a total letdown as a sequel, and completely undoes everything that I enjoyed about the original film in the first place.

title: The Gallows Act II

title: The Gallows Act II
review: The Gallows Act II is as bad as you all (wrongly) think The Gallows is.

title: The Gallows Act II
review: Despite a few (glaring) faults, The Gallows Act II still upstages the original, in every way. That still leaves a lot of room for disappointment, of course...

title: The Gallows Act II

title: The Gallows Act II
review: Lacks even the "missed opportunity" promise of the original, and even lesss frightening.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Stage Fright calls on us to treat ourselves with respect, even when it feels like our world (personal, political, environmental) is crashing down.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright is funny, fearless, and phenomenal. It's a must-see that may make you feel seen. And if not, may still make you cackle like its charismatic comedian. Don't miss it.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Jenny Slate is candid, genuine and endearing in her first stand-up special for Netflix. The standard special is elevated by home videos and documentary style vignettes.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: In her willingness to invite others into her romantic, family, and interior lives, Slate gives the distinct impression she's not performing at all.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: [Jenny] Slate commits from head to toe, which is to say that she moves like one of those inflatable advertising tubes outside of a car dealership. Her exaggerated physicality is matched only by her buzzing, infectious enthusiasm.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Slate gives us her all, and all of her, here. It's almost impossible not to fall for her.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Slate-like so many women-has more than one self, and she shows us a few of them in Stage Fright.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: I appreciated and related to Slate's honesty in these moments, and found Robespierre's choice to save them 'til the backend to be subtly powerful - the medicine hits harder because of the sugar we've been fed before.

title: Jenny Slate: Stage Fright
review: Robespierre sets up a playful rhythm between the performance material and the straight documentary that turns the project's two halves into a kind of conversation.

title: Badland
review: Despite using plenty of the usual tropes of the genre (silent, but appealing anti-hero, a woman in peril, an underdog fight against evil types, etc.) Badlands stumbles.

title: Badland

title: Badland
review: Lee's film never escapes its B-movie roots, nor does it try to, embracing its own pompousness.

title: Badland
review: Lee can't make a classic out of "Badland," but he respects the working parts of the genre, delivering a basic viewing experience, and one with occasional charms and bursts of compelling western action.

title: Badland
review: Another quick and dirty genre Western hampered by a dull leading man from the prolific writer-director Justin Lee.

title: Fire in Paradise
review: Whether you see Fire in Paradise as a cautionary tale, wake-up call, or simply great storytelling, it is paramount that you do see it.

title: Fire in Paradise
review: Fire in Paradise is a difficult watch. But it's a must-watch.

title: Fire in Paradise
review: ...what makes Fire in Paradise essential viewing isn't anything the subjects said or the directors captured. It comes from the amateurs, from the cellphone videos...

title: Holiday in the Wild
review: It's a nicey-nice movie and hollow but there's an audience for it somewhere

title: Holiday in the Wild
review: Elephant refuge is setting for love, life-changing moments.

title: Holiday in the Wild
review: Holiday in the Wild delivers on the cute elephants, and not much else.

review: Cute baby elephants dress up this limp romance, which has just enough holiday treacle to drown in

title: Holiday in the Wild
review: ...mostly watchable yet entirely forgettable...

title: Holiday in the Wild
review: Davis is a particular delight and all the elephants are adorable-and no other Christmas movie this year can claim to have Kristin Davis and elephants.

title: 2nd Date Sex

review: Alexandra Roach and George MacKay deserve each other in the sweetest possible way.

title: Gebo and The Shadow (Gebo et l'ombre)

title: Gebo and The Shadow (Gebo et l'ombre)
review: It may be directed by the world's oldest director, but it's one of Oliveira's most potent and rewarding titles from this late portion of his career, as well as an indication that he's lost none of his talents as one of the world's notable directors.

title: Gebo and The Shadow (Gebo et l'ombre)
review: 'Gebo' is an elemental thudding back to earth, body and soul entombed inside a dimly lit abode.

review: It defines Manoel de Oliveira's late period, during which his movies have continued to shrink in size and scope while remaining thematically expansive.

title: The Lion King
review: The best thing about The Lion King is that it stays faithfully close to the original...that's also the worst thing...I was lukewarm on the movie, but the package sold me...

title: The Lion King
review: The most stunningly realistic CGI you have seen to date - but the soul of the traditional animation is sorely missed.

title: The Lion King
review: The impressive visuals and the mix of reverence and playfulness to the original make this a movie worth seeing on the big screen.

title: The Lion King
review: I was not a big fan of the original 1994 movie, and I found this one to be about the same. It is a good film, with a good story and good music. What sets this film apart, however, is the technical wizardry that makes it look like a live action film.

title: The Lion King
review: Another remake that is made at the Disney level of craft but at the cost of originality and soul.

title: The Lion King
review: You're better off watching the 1994 version

title: The Lion King
review: It's not so much this is a bad adaptation as it's one that feels entirely unnecessary

title: The Lion King
review: It's Disney's version of the circle of life, but here it feels more like cannibalization.

title: The Lion King
review: It is ultimately just a reproduction of brand in an attempt to make a billion dollars. On that level, and only that level, The Lion King is a success.

title: The Lion King
review: A visionary triumph filled me with that Disney magic all over again.

title: The Lion King
review: The kids today, they want reality. Remember Beauty and the Beast? Remember how much better it was when that singing candlestick looked real? It was $1.2 billion better. Imagine that, but with lions.

title: The Lion King
review: The best news for any Lion King fan is that even if this version isn't to your liking, you only need to remember two words to make it all ok: hakuna matata.

title: Eli

review: You've seen haunted houses and medical horror movies before, but Eli plays with those conventions to develop fresh scares along with familiar tropes.

title: The Riot Act

title: The Dead Center
review: As riveting as it is fresh it's a slow and dreadful burn that, despite its detrimentally short run-time, manages to be one of the more intriguing, effective indie thrillers as of recent memory.

title: The Dead Center

title: The Dead Center

title: The Dead Center
review: "There's an unknowable boundary around the human experience, and if you pass beyond that boundary, you are quite simply fucked."

title: The Dead Center
review: [Billy] Senese... makes great use of the sound design, and glitchy visuals which are unnerving without resorting to cheap jump scares. But most importantly, The Dead Center gives us more [Shane] Carruth, and he brings the film to life.

title: The Dead Center
review: The film is in tune with the need to remain lucid and empathetic while in the maw of human extremity.

title: The Dead Center
review: Whether because of its seemingly open-ended finale, the powerful performances delivered by the actors, the direction and screenplay, or whether due to the thematic material it chews upon, this film is hard to forget.

title: The Dead Center

title: The Dead Center
review: Though the slow build and genre-bending approach won't be for everyone, this is an intelligent piece of filmmaking that demonstrates an acute understanding of horrors present in the mundane world.

title: The Dead Center

title: The Dead Center
review: You may come out of The Dead Center rooting for a sequel. I'm just rooting for whatever Senese's next movie is, even (especially?) if it keeps me awake at nights.

title: Making Montgomery Clift

title: Making Montgomery Clift

title: Making Montgomery Clift

title: Making Montgomery Clift

title: Making Montgomery Clift

title: Making Montgomery Clift
review: A fascinating exploration, but not of the man himself.

title: Making Montgomery Clift
review: You see how brilliant an actor Clift was. You see his love of the art of storytelling, developing characters with depth and dimension, and his willingness to put the final product over his own ego.

title: Making Montgomery Clift
review: The documentary manages to be not only a strikingly honest take on Clift but also a moving exploration of a lost relative and a meta-analysis of the ways media creates a biography.

title: Making Montgomery Clift
review: At its best, Making Montgomery Clift serves as a new, fresh take on the famously tragic queer icon Montgomery Clift.

title: Making Montgomery Clift
review: Making Montgomery Clift adds up to a wonderful watch and a film that is easily recommendable. It's juicy enough to get the gossip hound salivating, but contains such a great amount of care and heart...

review: Put simply: it's funny, albeit as broad as Mame's bottom.

title: Inside Lehman Brothers

title: Wonder Woman: Bloodlines

title: Wonder Woman: Bloodlines

title: Wonder Woman: Bloodlines
review: Bloodlines manages the balancing act of TV animation action with a surprisingly moving heart; a story about demanding mothers and their estranged daughters, and how deep the pain cuts when you feel that who you are is not enough for your loved ones.
