title: Haunt
review: While the unfolding of the film follows traditional patterns (you can roughly tell the order the youths will meet their grisly demise), it does it with certain panache.

title: Haunt
review: From what could have been the pot-of-gold at the end of the bloody rainbow for horror fans, results in a conspicuously suspense-free story about the systematic slaughtering of teenagers who should have known better on Halloween night.

title: Haunt
review: Funny, frightening, endlessly entertaining, and with a whole host of horrible villains and genuinely likable characters, it's one of the best horror movies of the year and a slasher all-timer in the making.

title: Haunt
review: Haunt ends up being a well-plotted, suitably sinister little shocker that proves to pack an agreeably malevolent little punch.

title: Haunt
review: Haunt is a brisk and stimulating ride, one you'll likely come out of feeling spooked and quite satisfied.

title: Candy Corn
review: The film's complexity emerges less from the gory slayings than from a more moral brand of confrontation.

title: Candy Corn
review: Candy Corn is stale and not nearly sweet enough for genre fans.

title: Candy Corn
review: In the end, Candy Corn is not a bad film - it's well made and everyone involved give it their all, but that's all trapped by a stale script and an inability to provide any real scary moments.

title: Candy Corn
review: Candy Corn is a love letter to Halloween and classic slashers of the 70's and 80's that is sure to be a holiday favorite for horror fans.

title: Candy Corn
review: It's a wonderful celebration of '80s genre cinema that writer/director/editor Josh Hasty put quite a bit of work into to retain the authenticity of its place in time.

title: Bloodline
review: By no means a perfect film... but it's a big swing and even though it doesn't always connect, I admire when a filmmaker tries for one.

title: Bloodline
review: Despite Seann William Scott's great work as the lead, Bloodline suffers from a lack of surprises in its story. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Bloodline
review: The dreamy, feverish, distinctly L.A. atmosphere in this serial-killer character study conceals a predictable, even banal screenplay.

title: Bloodline
review: A basic enough slasher. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Bloodline
review: It's difficult to imagine how Bloodline got made, given how its premise makes it feel like little more than an ill-fated pilot for a "Dexter" reboot.

title: Bloodline
review: I would not recommend this to the everyday filmgoer mostly in part to the heavy dollop of graphic imagery. But if you're looking for a slow simmer with an odd aftertaste, by all means, watch Bloodline.

title: Bloodline
review: Bloodline isn't the kind of movie that's going to win over a casual audience, but it's certainly a successful emulation of a subgenre too nasty and politically incorrect to be widespread today.

title: Bloodline
review: Bloodline delivers a lot of bloody fun.

title: Bloodline
review: ... delivers the requisite gore for genre fans, although the film stumbles in its attempt to navigate the psychological motives and moral complexity of its bloody brutality.

title: Bloodline
review: Jacobson and fellow screenwriters Avra Fox-Lerner and Will Honley aren't just here for the gory thrills.

title: Bloodline
review: "Bloodline" slips into a coma in its final act, but Jacobson's opening hour is engrossing, locating neat ways to disturb the audience.

title: Bloodline
review: Thanks to a great lead performance, a balanced handle of gore and violence, Bloodline is a fantastic character piece. A darkly twisted study of the ties of family and the lengths we'll go to protect them.

title: Running with the Devil
review: If you want to see a film about how the Columbian drug trade process works, then this movie is for you. If you like films like Sicario or Traffic, this may be right up your alley...

title: Running with the Devil
review: As long as the movie sticks with Fishburne it's a blast. Unfortunately, Cabell has bigger ambitions.

title: Running with the Devil
review: Running With the Devil is a dull, disjointed affair that unfortunately wastes the talents of its high-profile ensemble cast.

title: Running with the Devil
review: Jason Cabell's Running With The Devil might not be perfect, but at least it attempts to do something new with the oft-told tale of drugs moving across the Mexico/US border.

title: Running with the Devil
review: "It's Nic Cage. How bad could it be?"

title: Running with the Devil
review: The result is a misfire, but at least it's a rather convincing one.

title: Running with the Devil
review: This crime procedural is consistently fascinating as it charts the minutiae of the drug business -- but it also tries to be a bit too clever and neglects the characters in the process.

title: Running with the Devil
review: Another ho hum movie that follows Nicolas Cage's career down the rabbit hole.

title: Running with the Devil
review: It is less "Breaking Bad" than it is merely bad.

title: Running with the Devil
review: Despite featuring gunplay, nudity, illicit drugs and a setting that crosses two continents, Running With the Devil feels more like a leisurely, chemically enhanced stroll.

title: Running with the Devil
review: Running With the Devil stumbles as it laboriously works its way through the familiar piles of white-powder crime.

title: Running with the Devil
review: ... overflows with testosterone-fueled macho posturing without offering any substantially fresh insight into the contemporary drug trade.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: Don't bother telling anyone about this breezy yet uninspired romantic comedy, which needs more narrative depth to stand out in a crowded genre.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: Hoechlin is super dishy but he and Daddario have no chemistry together. Most of the time it is awkward and uncomfortable which is not what you want in this kind of escapist romcom.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: An unappealing RomCom that is so predictable it hurts.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: As charmless as it is laughless.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: There's some tremendous charm on display here. Both Alexandra Daddario and Tyler Hoechlin are romantic comedy gems, with Daddario in particular showing she's a future star.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: Struggles to come together as something sweet and silly, with director Elise Duran too dependent on improvisation and contrived screenwriting.

title: Can You Keep a Secret?
review: Can You Keep A Secret? is a sweet and funny romantic comedy with an incredibly charming leading duo in Tyler Hoechlin and Alexandra Daddario.

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: This gets pointless with every movie that comes out. [Full review in Spanish].

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: Hell House LLC: Lake of Fire features a creative story and some new scares that are very effective.

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: The latest entry in a tedious, chintzy franchise that's akin to the saddest haunted house attraction in cinematic form.

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: The bigger the film's structure grows the weaker the foundation becomes until it all comes crashing down.

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: Hell House LLC is far from a terrible offering. When its good, its skin-crawlingly terrifying, but when its bad its like a student film with a Marvel mindset of 'world expansion'.

title: Hell House LLC III: Lake of Fire
review: Hard to fault a filmmaker and franchise dying to evolve, but it's also hard not to feel let down by how Cognetti ends this Hell House LLC trilogy.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: Turner delivers a solid performance as a young woman coming to grips with an unknown force, and James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender maintain the frenemy bond we've grown to love.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: The movie's weaknesses make more glaring the movie's hollowness where the storyline's feminism once was.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: A stupendously dull series-ender without a shred of wit, narrative thrust or genuine emotional force.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: It didn't have to end this way...It didn't have to end with so little emotion, so little meaning - with a sad little speech about evolving, for Phoenix's sake.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: If future filmmakers can learn these lessons from the travesty of "Dark Phoenix," it won't have been a total waste.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: The final battle takes place aboard a moving train that feels like it's headed nowhere. At this point, it's a perfect metaphor for the "X-Men" series.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: The action scenes are by far the best part. Some of them are genuinely exciting. But there aren't nearly enough. It's mostly just boring talk about destiny, punctuated by zero jokes.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: But the dour, lifeless tone of the film is so pervasive that it undercuts all sense of joy.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: Dark Phoenix is a good superhero movie that people don't have faith in.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: X-Men: Dark Phoenix chronicles the last hurrah of the current cast with an ending that fits the franchise completely - with clunkiness, entertaining highs and forgettable lows.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: It's an ignominious end to a once-great franchise and a once-proud studio.

title: Dark Phoenix
review: Dark Phoenix nonetheless remains an intriguing and affecting film, particularly in its curt commentary on power and parenting.

title: The Last Photograph
review: The young romance sub-plot may be a tad unnecessary, and the film ends up rather slight and anticlimactic despite the hefty subject matter. There's no denying Huston's mastery though, both behind and in front of the camera.

title: The Last Photograph
review: A thriller, character study, and, to a lesser extent, coming of age romance. Yet it seamlessly balances all these elements to craft a story that grips as powerfully with its visuals as it does emotionally.

title: The Last Photograph
review: The Last Photograph features some fantastic performances and interesting elements, though this is not enough to make up for its sloppy editing and uneven script.

title: The Last Photograph
review: Although the story deals with emotionally wrenching themes, there is a coolness here which keeps us at arm's length.

title: The Last Photograph
review: Huston has conjured up a tough but rewarding story of real-life pain and hard-won healing.

title: Aladdin
review: Will Smith puts a fun spin on proceedings. He brings his "A" game, which we haven't seen in some of his recent outings.

title: Aladdin
review: Aladdin shows superior technical craftsmanship in so many aspects of the film, but its failure to reckon with a change of medium, bungling of story, and underwhelming characters, means that it is ultimately unsatisfying.

title: Aladdin
review: An unimaginative remake that can be entertaining but feels empty and forgettable.

title: Aladdin
review: There's enough here to make the film stand out on its own. Whether it stands out for the right reasons is up to the viewer.

title: Aladdin
review: An unsubtle, fast-moving film with plenty of jokes and a visual style that would suit a themed Las Vegas hotel, it's certainly not an all-time Disney great, but I can see it being a half-term hit.

title: Aladdin
review: The design is gawdy without the joy of camp. The pacing is manic. The editing is bizarre.

title: Aladdin
review: You can never unsee dance sequences directed by Guy Ritchie.

title: Aladdin
review: My wish is that this would have been a better movie. The Disney whimsy and magic is lacking in Aladdin.

title: Aladdin
review: Thankfully, Aladdin is not a shot-for-shot remake, which gives Ritchie room to provide his own unique take. In turn, he incorporates little touches amid clever chase scenes and entertaining dialogue to lift the film.

title: Aladdin
review: The film is breathless, while never taking a breath, and when everything is big, brassy, and bold, even a manic genie has trouble standing out.

title: Aladdin
review: "Aladdin" delivers the goods, especially when the music is playing, and while it may not be exactly what you wished for, it's close enough.

title: Aladdin
review: None of the filmmaking or acting really conveys that wonder of discovery; of falling in love. It's a facsimile of that feeling; a not-so-cheap copy. And, weirdly enough, it inspired in me only a small sense of loneliness.

title: Shaft
review: Whatever Shaft is saying about race, authority, age, gender or masculinity - which are interesting talking points no matter how badly fumbled they are - I keep going back to the rancid humour.

title: Shaft
review: There's not much else to this routine and sometimes retrograde actioner. Jackson deserves better material, but even so it's impressive how far he can carry it.

title: Shaft
review: This is a very strange movie... They've taken one of the coolest, suavest characters in movie history and cast him in this multigenerational "grumpy old dad" sitcom.

title: Shaft
review: Add this to the pile of crap legacy sequels like "A Good Day to Die Hard," and "Blues Brothers 2000."

title: Shaft
review: Not having a stronger, more serious plot means the film will likely appeal more to Shaft newbies than to Shaft devotees.

title: Shaft
review: It's a new way to approach an old character and it tries harder to give its main characters something to do than a lot of its colleagues do, and there is something worthy in that.

title: Shaft
review: If you are of a younger generation you will relate to many of the pop culture references that Shaft (2019) provides.

title: Shaft
review: Although a bit out of place for its time, the fifth Shaft film packs enough gunfights, wisecracks, and thrills to make it a decent entry in the series. Samuel L. Jackson fans will not be disappointed, and neither will fans of Richard Roundtree.

title: Shaft
review: For those of us weaned on 1970s and '80s television, Shaft feels like dozing off on a shag rug - an unconscious nod into a long, open loop of nostalgia that conjures an entire, and unique, set of sounds and textures.

title: Shaft
review: The messages are bad and the movie is bad. It's plain and clear why the studio dumped this on Netflix internationally.

title: Shaft
review: The proceedings are still intermittently fun, especially because of Jackson who is clearly in his element here.

title: Shaft
review: The script feels like it's been in mothballs since the term "metrosexual" was still a big deal in the mid-2000s.

title: Being Frank
review: Being Frank threatens to sink under the weight of life-altering deception played for laughs.

title: Being Frank
review: It's hard to say who's more at fault: writer, director, actors, pool boy.

title: Being Frank
review: Director Miranda Bailey put together an overall enjoyable film reminiscent of the sleeper films of an era of filmmaking that is altogether lost

title: Being Frank
review: Inconsistent lurches between romp comedy and soap opera melodrama detract as the plot noose tightens and the truth closes in on Frank.

title: Being Frank
review: ...a tonally inconsistent, unsatisfying film that is neither funny nor insightful...

title: Being Frank
review: Jim Gaffigan mugs as a dad with two families. A few interesting pieces, but it's basically a TV sitcom version of a British slamming doors farce.

title: Being Frank
review: No faulting a game cast, but even talented actors can't make this creaky and marginally creepy farce hit enough of the right notes.

title: Being Frank
review: Bailey's film ultimately feels like a misguided attempt to complicate male entitlement by humanizing it.

title: Being Frank
review: A frantic and desperate attempt to extract some laughs from a misguided premise.

title: Being Frank
review: The movie has a great message for kids and teens...stand up and be heard...call the adults out...especially if you feel they are wrong and in this case, Frank is oh so wrong...

title: Being Frank
review: Being Frank works so hard to make its male abuser sympathetic, while virtually ignoring the inner lives of the women unfortunate enough to be in his path, that each moment of empathy feels unearned and every laugh regrettable.

title: Being Frank
review: It needs strong performances to elevate its mediocrity, so instead we are left with a film straining for modest goals it cannot achieve.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: Given the vastness of the label's history, Huber does manage to cover a lot of ground in its relatively brief runtime.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: Anyone who has a real love for music will want to see and learn from "Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes" and the many amazing talents those two old white German Jewish immigrant refugees brought to us all.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: Even if jazz is not your thing, Huber's rich musical history of its preeminent label is something to sink into.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: The label is generally considered unparalleled in its impact on music, singular catalogue, and the artistic freedom it afforded its musicians. Or should I say affords, since the film makes abundantly clear that Blue Note is very much alive and well.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: When the landscape of documentary films is embodied by a spectrum of truly groundbreaking work, Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes just feels a bit lackluster.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: I am grateful to Sophie Huber for opening my eyes-and ears. She has made a memorable film that jazz buffs shouldn't miss.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: Great interviews; great music; great Black history. Enough said.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: The documentary proves that the history and mythology of American jazz is as intoxicating as the music itself.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: While it's not the only cinematic or retrospective look at the artist friendly outfit started by Alfred Lion and Francis Wolff in 1939, it might be the most personal and personable.

title: Blue Note Records: Beyond the Notes
review: Masterfully directed by Sophie Huber and perfectly edited by Russell Greene with evocative photos and footage that bring back memories of the pioneers of jazz.

title: Gags the Clown
review: Gags The Clown has a few issues, but it works where it counts. It is a scary, intense watch with an engaging premise. And it is all brought to life by an excellent cast.

title: Gags the Clown
review: Like too many found-footage films, Gags devotes too much of its running time to its characters arguing with and throwing insults at each other.

title: Gags the Clown
review: GAGS THE CLOWN is no sideshow pushover. It's like MOCKINGBIRD meets SLENDER MAN but way, way better.

title: Gags the Clown
review: The found-footage approach utilized here doesn't really bring anything of value to the proceedings. The combination of humor and horror never quite pans out either.

title: Gags the Clown
review: Another poorly executed, found-footage movie that adds to an already-overflowing pile of forgettable titles just like it.

title: Gags the Clown
review: It all adds up to an offbeat, unusual horror film that totally has its own identity.

title: Gags the Clown
review: As someone who is always up for more clown-based horror hijinks, Gags feels like something of a letdown; there is a genuinely good idea at its core, but his approach never really works for me as a viewer.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Maybe the point is to highlight the way we are all sleepwalking into disaster with next-to-no resistance, but the film doesn't seem complex enough to offer it that much credit.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: It's tough to distinguish a movie trying to wring humor from a deliberately enervated take on a typically breathless subgenre, from one that's just dull and ineffective.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: The fact that Jarmusch is saying we're all zombies and not in a subtle way just makes the film more enjoyable, acknowledging that we all have our own likes, or addictions.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Why did Jarmusch pick a zombie film? That's possibly a question that will pop up on most viewers' minds, especially Jarmusch devotees, and for the first two thirds of the film it does seem like the director wants to have a bit fun with the genre.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Jim Jarmusch's B-movie satire rises slowly, brings our attention to its stench, and proceeds to wander aimlessly, disappointingly caught in its own daze.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Jarmusch has put out a very different horror movie for the year (and for him). The Dead Don't Die is a fun time in the cinema and actually has more to say than you might think.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Alas, maybe the dead don't die, but this time, too many of Jarmusch's jokes do.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: The Dead Don't Die has all the components of a cult classic but was not executed properly. It's all over the place & not even a stellar performance by Adam Driver can save it.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: The commentary is valuable and timely, but the narrative and formal vehicle -- even with its wonderful moments -- is not that solid. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: The problem is that integrating so many characters ends up turning the plot into a real disaster. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: Uniting all the Jarmusch output are achingly cool casts, indescribably eclectic and wonderful soundtracks - and a joyous disregard for the expectations of anyone who walks into one of his films expecting it to obey the rules of the alleged genre.

title: The Dead Don't Die
review: [I]ts slow and safe tone makes it one of the dullest entries in the genre so far. You will probably like it if you read the New Yorker.

title: Wayne
review: Forthright and humble in that down to Earth Aussie way, Wayne Gardner proves that there is no sports superstar like an Aussie sports superstar.

title: Wayne
review: In an early interview with Gardner's sister, she says that he's the "golden child." Wayne has every intention of maintaining Gardner's golden glow.

title: Wayne
review: The film deftly touches on Australia's cultural cringe as Gardner admits how his class made him feel unworthy of the accolades he had earned.

title: Wayne
review: You don't have to be a motorsport fan to richly enjoy Kiwi producing duo Matthew Metcalfe and Fraser Brown's (McLaren, the upcoming Scott Dixon doco Born Racer) latest work, but it will certainly help.

title: Wayne
review: I'm not into motorbikes, yet this documentary revved along in my mind in the days after I saw it.

title: Wayne
review: What the doco Wayne does very well is chart the immense distance - both literally and metaphorically - Gardner had to traverse to become the first Australian to win the coveted 500cc World Championship.

title: Wayne
review: Directed by Jeremy Sims, Wayne is snapshot of '80s male culture; a tall-but-true story of a life lived at full tilt by a bloke with a singular vision and the audacity to deliver on it.

title: Wayne
review: ...a pretty straightforward, rather hagiographic biography that'll please fans but won't do much for newcomers.

title: Low Tide
review: It's a film that doesn't overstay its welcome but never really announces itself either.

title: Low Tide
review: Low Tide stands out because of its performances, it's like a surprisingly good appetizer-sampler of the best Generation Z actors.

title: Low Tide
review: Low Tide is a promising start to McMullin's career as a director, even though it plays out as a standard crime drama with a coming of age twist.

title: Low Tide
review: A fresh faced cast bring talent and energy to this tale of life and crime on the Jersey shore. It is under the radar but should be sought out.

title: Low Tide
review: If not a great movie, it's just good enough to make me curious to see what the filmmaker has up his sleeve next. More importantly, it helps make his thoughtfully meditative debut worthy of a look.

title: Low Tide
review: The atmospheric approach to "Low Tide" serves filmmaker Kevin McMullin well.

title: Low Tide
review: LOW TIDE may have problems, but for a feature film debut for McMullin, there is promise of what he could do in the future.

title: Low Tide
review: Low Tide is a tactile, explosive study of masculinity, an exploration of what boys do, what makes them do it, and how they need to learn to stick up to each other.

title: Low Tide
review: Low Tide knows where it came from but adequately avoids succumbing to nostalgia. Instead, Kevin McMullin paints a darker portrait of the forgotten youth of the Jersey Shore that is as violent as it is strangely charming...

title: Low Tide
review: Boring drama about teenage boys whose lives are derailed when they find some gold coins.

title: Low Tide
review: ... struggles to maintain consistent suspense, but the visually murky film effectively depicts some morally conflicted mischief, bolstered by charismatic young actors who develop a convincing rapport.

title: Low Tide
review: It's a bit jarring to see these young characters act out a fairly generic crime tale...

title: Vita & Virginia
review: It's not a pretty picture, but it's a true one, ad same-sex couples who've "been there" are sure to be thankful for Vita and Virgina as much as the Bloomsbury adepts who'll be certain to flock to it.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: Vita & Virginia just can't overcome its faults and succumbs to being another well-made period piece that misses its mark.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: Never mind the class struggle, mental illness, or heteronormativity at every corner: Chanya Button's film can't figure out which way to look.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: For those who remember The Hours or Sally Potter's Orlando, this is a terrific companion piece.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: It's an insufferable venture that completely misses the mark, despite the strong material at its foundation that begs to be explored.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: For many the film will ultimately succeed or fall on Elizabeth Debicki's depiction of Woolf as a wanly frail creature, forever on the verge of falling apart.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: The film finds greater depth and dimension in its side romances than in the one placed front-and-center.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: Lovely to look at, and the content is interesting from both historical and literary perspectives. But, the relationship at its center is never quite as all-consuming as it should be.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: An especially simple-minded, pandering piece of art-house entertainment.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: Arterton and Debicki give outstanding performances, and their onscreen chemistry is palpable, which makes up for everything else this movie lacks.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: The decorous chat, evocative period décor and killer costumes do scratch a Downton Abbey itch.

title: Vita & Virginia
review: Vita & Virginia... too often fails to break its period-piece shackles.

title: Ladyworld
review: The lack of clarity distracts from whatever the story is with these girls.

title: Ladyworld
review: Trouble is, the incessant soundtrack of noises and ethereal voices really does grate after a while, eroding any sustained suspense just as events take on an increasingly surreal hue.

title: Ladyworld
review: An accomplished exercise in the setting of mood, Ladyworld's score, acting and script are interesting and layered.

title: Ladyworld
review: It's immediately clear the film's intention is to disorientate and disturb audiences, so it's a shame it does nothing more than irritate. Never has a so-called thriller been less thrilling and more forgettable

title: Ladyworld
review: Ladyworld the DVD winds up looking great, and promising intrigue, but ultimately stumbling along and failing to give me anything that might help me delve a little deeper into this world.

title: Ladyworld
review: "This party would be a lot more fun if it were over," a gloomy girl says at one point in the film. We couldn't agree with you more.

title: Ladyworld
review: ... taps into adolescent angst yet never provides the slightest incentive for emotional investment in these wayward characters.

title: Ladyworld
review: Kramer crafts an aura of unnerving apocalyptic certitude that grows in power as events progress, the final scene a breathlessly haunting coda that sent chills racing up and down my spine.

title: Ladyworld
review: Cerebral and forceful, [Ladyworld] will have you deliberating its themes for days after.

title: Ladyworld
review: Ladyworld is an intriguing experiment that runs out of steam.

title: Ladyworld
review: Ladyworld manages to capture the perfect balance between the moments of tension and uneasiness with moments of teenage life.

title: Ladyworld
review: Inspired costuming and score create a true 'other world', but a lack of clarity on a couple of key elements leaves the viewer a little muddled. Overall though, Ladyworld is a solidly made film, one that raises an interesting range of debates.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: Goes up in flames despite a stellar cast.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: A stellar cast, skilled musical score composers, and a solid set of inspirations combine to little beyond an uninspiring drama at best, or a leery piece of pulp deserving of eyerolls at worst.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: So ludicrously over-the-top...

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: [I]t all turns out to be ridiculously far-fetched and dated in feel.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: Trouble is, there are too many leaps of illogic to sustain the seeds of a good idea, and with so many engrossing small-screen offerings around, the ante for delivering the thriller-killer goods has been well and truly upped.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: You're going to want to break out your crime cliche bingo card early, lest you miss the full house.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: For a film so desperate to be Zodiac, everyone would have seen this one coming.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: As far as you can work out, the film isn't aiming for slippery Lynchian dream logic or head-scratching dead ends, just stumbling into that arena through sheer confusion.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: A surfeit of plot succeeds only in confusing the story, not complicating it in the kind of way that might have made its big twist the sort of jaw-dropping revelation it clearly wants to be.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: An entertaining ride into dark heart of evil.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: Night Hunter might not leave a lasting impact but it's an exciting thriller full of killer twists and turns which will keep you guessing and the amazing cast alone makes it worth checking out.

title: Night Hunter (Nomis)
review: ill-judged, silly and grim

title: Child's Play
review: I had fun with the idea the film was pushing with mankind being the victim of its own evil ways but I wanted more.

title: Child's Play
review: Fans of the schlocky Chucky series will not find the same kind of absurd fun in this unneeded reboot.

title: Child's Play
review: This just wasn't a good movie to me. I liked the consciousness of the serial killer, but the AI just did not land.

title: Child's Play
review: Short, entertaining, stupid, absolutely insane. Could have been a lot worse, but it could've been way better.

title: Child's Play
review: While not as subversive as Holland's cult classic, Klevberg's polished version is a delightfully vicious ode to its campy origins, proving that a remake can be worthwhile if made with enough creativity and a current social awareness.

title: Child's Play
review: Despite how impressive the new Chucky looks - rendered with a blend of practical on-set puppet work and digital enhancements - he is never scary.

title: Child's Play

title: 15 Minutes of War (L'intervention)
review: Suspenseful from beginning to end and populated with unique characters who are a mix of "The Dirty Dozen" and "Dirty Harry."

title: 15 Minutes of War (L'intervention)
review: Solid, cliche-ridden B-movie about snipers trying to save schoolkids in French Colonial Africa.

title: See You Soon
review: Only the most hopeless of romantics will come close to buying the lovelorn theatrics in this eye-rolling melodrama.

title: See You Soon
review: The film isn't without its charms thanks to its unabashedly absurd script and some very amusing references to the real-life world of soccer.

title: See You Soon
review: Sweet slow-burn romance has some sex, stereotypes.

title: See You Soon
review: Deathly dull Russo-American romance whose leading lady displays all the warmth of a Bond villain.

title: Every Time I Die
review: With just a singular location and five characters Michael and Katzir hurdle us into a mind-bending metaphysical thriller that is, truly, remarkable.

title: Every Time I Die
review: A superior indie riddle and a strikingly singular film.

title: Every Time I Die
review: Every Time I Die could have easily been overpowered by superfluous gore or supernatural hokum but instead, it's a captivating little tale about self-image, with a mystical and poignant touch.

title: Every Time I Die
review: Even though it may not reach the heights of the films that have influenced it, it is certainly an enjoyable and worthy experience.

title: Every Time I Die
review: Every Time I Die lives up to both the evocative nature and the weirdness of its title.

title: Every Time I Die
review: The best no-budget indie thriller of the summer, maybe of the year.

title: The Night Sitter
review: gleefully ghoulish horror

title: The Night Sitter
review: Would I recommend The Night Sitter? Only if you're playing a gag on a friend and want to subject them to a really bad time, but other than that, save your precious time and do anything else.

title: The Night Sitter
review: Christmas came early this year, and while The Night Sitter isn't the exact gift you asked for, it serves its purpose.

title: The Night Sitter
review: The film never seems to find its stride but the prospect and groundwork were most definitely present - but as a reasonably entertaining 90-minute paranormal slasher, The Night Sitter is ultimately worth a watch as a late night romp.

title: The Night Sitter
review: The Night Sitter is an unpretentious and enjoyable little film with sympathetic leads and plenty of personality.

title: The Night Sitter
review: The Night Sitter is a bright, energetic, smart genre exercise that never takes itself too seriously while making sure that all its bases are covered.

title: The Night Sitter
review: A visually thoughtful film, let down by a few plot niggles, The Night Sitter is nonetheless an entertaining Yuletide comedy horror.

title: The Night Sitter
review: reinvests Yuletide imagery with something more Satanically paranormal, inviting The Evil Dead in for a Christmas snack... like any festive bonbon, might make you feel a little sick, but only because it has such an addictively sweet centre.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Uneven Nicolas Cage action movie; violence, drug use.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Too often stumbles with its inconsistent and schlocky take on the geriatric revenge thriller movie.

title: A Score to Settle
review: An entertaining and well-paced film, "A Score to Settle" is Nicolas Cage at his best - deeply intense with a little bit of crazy mixed in for good measure.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Suggests something that's just within reach, but isn't there yet.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Nicolas Cage has practically cornered the market on these sorts of assembly-line revenge thrillers, including this predictably lackluster entry

title: A Score to Settle
review: Nicolas Cage chose the right amount of restraint in his portrayal of the unhappy, obsessed lead character in "A Score to Settle." But he has one almost over-the-top scene that will stay with you after the credits roll.

title: A Score to Settle
review: At second glance, A Score to Settle reveals itself as a swarm of cliches that ring louder than bullets.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Cage's eccentricity once had a certain perverse charm, but in a dreary potboiler like this it's merely tiresome.

title: A Score to Settle
review: The dialogue is atrocious.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Cage at least makes a little bit of an effort, but since the film gives him nothing to play off of, those efforts are mostly in vein and after a while, you find yourself hoping that Crazy Cage will finally kick in.

title: A Score to Settle
review: A Score to Settle ends with lots of bullets but with very little bang.

title: A Score to Settle
review: Starts out stupid, gets even stupider, and then it ends, which is one of the most satisfying things to be said about it.

title: Coyote Lake
review: Although Coyote Lake doesn't deviate too much from the narrative you would expect, it's the details Seligman incorporates throughout that make this thriller a promising debut.

title: Coyote Lake
review: Minutes in, it's clear that Coyote Lake is not your run-of-the-mill U.S.-Mexico border story...you get a sense of a filmmaker truly in control of the tone of her film, a bellwether, one hopes, of even more assured films to come.

title: Coyote Lake
review: The atypical relationship between Ester and Teresa is something new for audiences...

title: Coyote Lake
review: Coyote Lake is hardly a shallow enterprise. Its still waters still run pleasurably deep.

title: Dead Water
review: ... the filler in between the tension gave time for all of that apprehensiveness to drain away. What's left felt more like an anchor than a buoy.

title: Dead Water
review: A promising menage-a-trois at sea thriller that sinks more often than it swims

title: Enter the Anime
review: Enter the Anime is an hour-long infomercial for Netflix original anime that wastes everyone's time.

title: Enter the Anime
review: Obnoxious faux documentary has cursing, violence.

title: Enter the Anime
review: The individual artist interviews might be worth fast-forwarding to, but as a whole, Enter the Anime is not recommended for beginners, otaku, or anyone except those with a taste for cringe.

title: Enter the Anime
review: Enter the Anime is sponsored content winkingly performing cheeky quirk and self-awareness in that it's been promoted as a documentary. It is, undoubtedly, an ad for Netflix anime series.

title: Enter the Anime
review: Enter the Anime is orientalist at worst and reductionist at best. ...reducing what could have been a documentary to get people involved in the culture to nothing more than a 60-minute ad-roll for Netflix animation.

title: Madness in the Method
review: Messy, tonally inconsistent, offensive, and ultimately pointles

title: Madness in the Method
review: If anything, fans of Kevin Smith's View Askewniverse can use this as something to hold us over until Jay and Silent Bob Reboot.

title: Madness in the Method
review: It seems that in this sense, perhaps Mewes would have been better off in making his debut about someone other than himself...

title: Madness in the Method
review: Jason Mewes' satirical metabiopic sees 'Jason Mewes' turn to method acting to escape his stereotyping as stoner sidekick Jay

title: Madness in the Method
review: Shamelessly self-indulgent film-as-therapy for director-star Jason Mewes, Madness in the Method will fitfully entertain Askewniverse fans, though it's ultimately too scattershot to consistently satisfy.

title: Madness in the Method
review: Madness in the Method is a solid first directorial entry for Jason Mewes. There were enough laughs and surprises that I was thoroughly entertained. Looking forward to his next film.

title: Madness in the Method
review: There's something in the self-aware approach that's worth exploring, but Mewes doesn't want to be entirely honest with himself.

title: UglyDolls
review: Obviously, a children's film has to be on the nose, but the film's unwillingness to explore its own message in depth is disappointing.

title: UglyDolls
review: Even undemanding kids in need of distraction might find it hard not to get restless during this word-heavy, woke animation.

title: UglyDolls
review: With the school holidays on, this movie is a colourful and entertaining 90 minutes for kids under 10. The songs are easy on the ear and there are a couple of good jokes for the adult minders.

title: UglyDolls
review: Sadly, the Ugly Dolls animated feature is anything but plush, a combination of dog-eared, deja-vu moments and care-worn plotting that will leave even the most upbeat young moviegoer a little disappointed.

title: UglyDolls
review: [A] word-heavy, woke animation...The messaging comes with sledgehammer subtlety, the visuals offer a world of candy-coloured dullness and, despite a stellar voice cast veteran animator and director Kelly Asbury just can't bring the affair to life.

title: UglyDolls
review: A 90-minute commercial for toys disguised as an entertainment.

title: UglyDolls
review: Not so much a movie as a contemplative space wherein the viewer ... explores the shifting dynamic between the eponymous plush toys and the hegemony of play.

title: UglyDolls
review: Thankfully, the voice cast is packed with popstars who are great at pouring sparky attitude into their performances.

title: UglyDolls
review: Certain scenes may scare more sensitive children but, on the whole, UglyDolls is cutely done, and it earns extra plaudits for being an animation for younger kids that attempts to address age-relevant issues of individuality.

title: UglyDolls
review: While the design is visually striking there's nothing beyond the paper-thin, by-the-numbers nature of UglyDolls.

title: UglyDolls
review: This paean to body positivity and living your own truth is more than welcome, but you just wish UglyDolls' message could be more charmingly argued, adroitly assembled and just plain funny.

title: UglyDolls
review: UglyDolls' worst feature is that it's rather bland. For a movie about embracing one's differences, it does seem to be pretty much identical to the many other 'summer holiday kids movies' out there.

title: Long Shot
review: Unlike Knocked Up, which also featured Rogen as a schlub paired off with a woman seemingly well out of his league, this works hard to show why both characters would be into each other despite their surface differences.

title: Long Shot
review: Long Shot may not be the return of the romcom, but it's certainly a real return to form.

title: Long Shot
review: ...despite the clunky, unimaginative script and the by-the-numbers direction, Long Shot is saved by the exact gimmick that probably green-lit it in the first place: Theron and Rogen.

title: Long Shot
review: Broad appeal with Long Shot as it plays to the Seth Rogen fan base, the rom com watchers, and anyone that enjoys political comedies. It's smarter and funnier than you'll want to give it credit for.

title: Long Shot
review: The way Long Shot differentiates itself from the sexist sitcom cliche is by exploring the difficulty men have in ceding power to women, even if-perhaps especially if-the women are clearly more skilled and intelligent.

title: Long Shot
review: It's not a new Valentine's Day classic perhaps, but there are enough warm, fuzzy feelings, along with many laughs, to qualify for date night.

title: Long Shot
review: It has everything you want in a romantic comedy and more.

title: Long Shot
review: Long Shot somehow makes it all work

title: Long Shot
review: Even when the story is treading well-worn territory, Rogen and Theron are so authentic and lively together that you don't care you know exactly where it's going, you're just happy to be along for the ride.

title: Long Shot
review: Though it lacks a certain edge, Long Shot is a tight, funny, and warm comedy with a ton of heart and two fantastic performances at its center.

title: Long Shot
review: While flirting with some disturbing political truths, the film sometimes mistakes fatuity for freshness. If anything, it works as a showcase for the actors.

title: Long Shot
review: Long Shot is actually romantic and genuinely a comedy.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: This is a film rooted in a ludicrous concept that doesn't just work, but excels because of the amount of heart that has gone into making it. It's earnest, endearing, and well worth a Pika.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: It's just nice, it's a nice pleasant thing. I think if you yourself have Pokemon nostalgia you'll probably get some enjoyment out of this, just don't expect to be surprised by the plot.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Detective Pikachu is a fun family movie that can be enjoyed by many. It's a love letter to the world of Pokémon and easily the best video game movie made.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Detective Pikachu wears its influences on its sleeve, and has the sensibilities of a Stephen Spielberg-produced picture.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Rob Letterman's film is a standard kids' movie blend of knockabout comedy and CGI fantasy action, but Detective Pikachu himself is a proper star.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Solid family fun.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Smart, imaginative and sweet, Detective Pikachu offers something for everyone.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Even though Pokemon implores you to "catch 'em all," this is one you're going to want to release back into the wild.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: I found this weirdly diverting... It's a counterintuitive fit for this character, and I kind of liked that about it.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: A seriously weird and heartfelt film jam-packed with action and chock full of Pokemon - what more could you ask for?

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: While by no means perfect, 'Pokemon Detective Pikachu' can nevertheless comfortably lay claim to being the best videogame adaptation ever made.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu
review: Pokémon: Detective Pikachu is a rather silly idea in conception, but in execution, it's a pretty compelling tale that features plenty of twists and turns, and well-rendered CGI.

title: Fast Color
review: A very rich, lively, humane mess.

title: Fast Color
review: [Gugu Mbatha-Raw] delivers a laudable, restrained, and complex performance. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Fast Color
review: A terrific movie that juggles several different genres with enormous skill and economy.

title: Fast Color
review: A subdued take on the superhero film...

title: Fast Color
review: It's a strange and enticing mix: a superhero origin story and sci-fi paranormal effects mix with apocalyptic allegory.

title: Fast Color
review: Fast Color, a low-budget, sci-fi indie drama (...) operates within the superhero sub-genre, but without the plastic, toy-selling bombast these films have become known for.

title: Fast Color
review: ... don't confuse Fast Color for a standard superhero tale. This isn't a story in which heroes level cities in their quest to defeat evil, but is one of unconditional love, creation, and sacrifice.

title: Fast Color
review: Fast Color really is a lovely, quiet movie... Lorraine Touissant steals the show as the matriarch of the family and Gugu Mbatha-Raw is as magnetic as ever as the lead.

title: Fast Color
review: Through visions of family and generational trauma, Fast Color stands tall as a specialty listing, something I would call a "Pre-Power" story. When that power comes alive, the results reach fantastical heights.

title: Fast Color
review: As more and more filmgoers learn to speak in the modern pidgin language of comic book, let's hope Fast Color is a sign of conversations to come.

title: Fast Color
review: The more you find out, the more [Julia] Hart's film settles into a kind of ponderous groove that eventually works its way into a solid story arc but struggles to register on the Richter scale.

title: Fast Color
review: One of those small, mighty movies that can easily slip under the radar in a busy season of blockbusters.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: The Coming Race doesn't have the love and affection of its predecessor, nor does it have a sense of discipline or focus, and unfortunately falls flat.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: As much as this premise could make for a good time, it's largely a bore and a mess.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: Call it mindless schlock if that makes you feel better about liking it, but campy movies are supposed to be ridiculous and entertaining. Iron Sky: The Coming Race is light years from the latter.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: Noisy and unfunny, still pawing at the same obvious political targets while expanding its capacity for mayhem, hoping to wow viewers instead of tickle them with relentless absurdity.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: The Coming Race might not sell the need for this absurd series to continue, it at least provides a reason to go back and watch the original, and help its creators get the money they need to try to recapture their uniquely bizarre form of movie magic.

title: Iron Sky: The Coming Race
review: ... there's something so refreshing, so pure, about the Iron Sky series in what it attempts, that audiences can't help but get swept up in its wake.

title: Little Woods
review: DaCosta, Thompson, and James have created something tense and timely and empathetic in Little Woods, further expanding the Western genre and adding another slice of American life to it.

title: Little Woods
review: [Tessa] Thompson's forceful, charismatic performance brings life to what could have been a relentlessly grim film, but it also unbalances the drama somewhat.

title: Little Woods
review: This is a film of high tension about two sisters living on the edge of ruin in the farthest northern reaches of North Dakota. One slip up and they could end up homeless, or in jail. The only things they have to rely on are their wits and each other.

title: Little Woods
review: A predictable narrative given rich contours...

title: Little Woods
review: The film may not look impressive, but I am impressed by how [writer-director Nia] DaCosta introduces complications into this already complicated story without straining for effect.

title: Little Woods
review: Though it may be on the nose at times, Little Woods is a tense and emotional look at the political issues we're arguing about today that are affecting people's lives.

title: Little Woods
review: Little Woods acts as a slow-burning drama that too often extinguishes the tension just as things are heating up.

title: Little Woods
review: Little Woods is a film that more people need to see, as it is not only a compelling survival drama, but it is a enlightening examination at a slice of Americana, an involving crime western and a touching look at a strong sisterly bond.

title: Little Woods
review: Little Woods can be bleak, but it's a good choice if you're looking for some substance among the Hollywood blockbusters out this season.

title: Little Woods
review: The directorial debut by Nia DaCosta is a stunning, deep and thoughtful portrait of two marginalised women in America forgotten by city folk and the political class.

title: Little Woods
review: Writer-director Nia DaCosta's debut feature is a bravura and, at times, bleak look at women living on the poverty line in small-town America.

title: Little Woods
review: Visually striking. Comparisons to Debra Granik's Winter's Bone and Leave No Trace are fitting...

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: As Qiao, Zhao [Tao] perfectly captures this complex character full of rage, emotion, and determination.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Jia Zhangke has crafted a razor-sharp study of alienation and the corrosiveness of the patriarchy in contemporary China. And Tao is a revelation.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Jia Zhangke highlights the changes China have been experiencing during the last decades, as tradition has succumbed completely to technology, speed and the relentless pursue of money.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: ...a mesmerizing mood piece about personal alienation and national dislocation.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: For anyone with a long investment in Jia Zhengke's artistry, it's not hard to find what he achieves here to be another masterwork.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Zhao is one of the greatest actresses in cinema, and her journey in Ash Is Purest White is hardboiled and subtly melodramatic.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Led be immensely pained performances from Tao Zhao and Fan Liao, who carry the weight of guilt, betrayal and a rapidly changing society on their shoulders, the film brings in to focus the ways in which forces larger than ourselves end up molding our lives

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: 'Ash Is Purest White' forces audiences to stop, stand still, and question what's lost in the wake of China's fast march forward.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Cinephiles craving something more substantial than Hollywood's fast and furious follies would do well to spare a couple of hours for Ash Is The Purest White this weekend.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: An intimate story of romance, betrayal and loss gets framed against the sweeping, epic backdrop of radical, socio-economic changes in China.

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Jia Zhangke creates atmospheres and images of great poetic breath that are full of suggestive power and meaning. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Ash Is Purest White
review: Another valuable film with a true Jiang Zhang-Ke seal. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: A very long time coming, The Curse of La Llorona, ultimately fails to entertain much less scare.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: It would have been fresh to set this film in Mexico, centred on a Mexican family and have it steeped in an entirely different landscape and culture. Instead, it's the same story seen many times before - an innocent American family targeted by ghouls.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: The appearance by Father Perez marks this as another entry in The Conjuring Universe, but I daresay that a character from a different Warner property -- say, Clint Eastwood's drug smuggler from The Mule -- would have made for a more interesting crossover.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: The Curse of La Llorona whitewashes iconic Mexican folklore and replaces it with tense scares but nothing of substance.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: The movie delivers on the jump scares, and gets extra points for exploring Mexican folklore. Yet, The Curse of La Llorona suffers from generic plot and easily forgettable characters.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: Director Michael Chaves ramps up the Spielbergian flair in the final act, with a spookhouse run of more playful malevolence than perfunctory motion. But after two acts of overly telegraphed terror, you just don't fear the weeper.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: Velasquez doesn't have many lines...but she uses the ones she has to make as much of an impact as possible.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: This is a competently made film. [...] It is not particularly original.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: [The Curse of La Llorona] pack[s] a few good punches in terms of scares, and the overall visual are rather beautiful, but I just felt like the writers didn't do the story justice.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: The lack of creativity and innovation kills the film stone dead. It is clear that the filmmakers need to reinvent the formula and fast, before it dries out like an exhumed corpse.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: It lacks the punch and pure terror that a stronger script and more visceral approach could achieve with the legendary weeping woman.

title: The Curse of La Llorona
review: Pretty much everything about the project is too generic to really make an impression.

title: Teen Spirit
review: 'Teen Spirit' does feel like a first feature, with the familiar beats and characters BUT it also serves as taster of what Minghella will make next.

title: Teen Spirit
review: Teen Spirit doesn't really know what it's saying, but it likes it anyways. That just isn't enough.

title: Teen Spirit
review: This should be right up my alley as I love the music and Elle Fanning as an actress, but it's hard to like a movie when you don't root for the lead character.

title: Teen Spirit
review: We can't detect any other intention than to depict with a pretty mise-en-scène the story of a generic Amaia Romero. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: Through it all, [Max] Minghella believes in Violet, as does [Elle] Fanning. They both give her character their all, keeping a tight focus on her ups and downs along her journey.

title: Teen Spirit
review: There are only a few moments to enjoy in Teen Spirit, but it is only in those moments and then you will soon forget. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: Minghella's merit is his ingenious way of giving life to the interior world of his character. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: It should work for music lovers, and those who are looking for a familiar story, told in an original way. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: There is more to it than meets the eye.

title: Teen Spirit
review: Elle Fanning sets the screen on fire saving this film from oblivion. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: A more than acceptable... start for [the film's] debut director. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Teen Spirit
review: The movie can feel a bit slow and melodramatic, but otherwise, it's quite entertaining and leaves us with a clear message about opportunities and fate. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Wedding Guest
review: The story feels realistic in a way that this sort of noir material doesn't, always... They're human, and I rooted for them.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Basically, it's Double Indemnity... I thoroughly enjoyed this film.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Something you will have to seek out, but Michael Winterbottom is always worth seeking out.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Director Michael Winterbottom seems to be too interested in psychology to be able to deliver an effective action thriller. However, great leads and an air of mystery hold your attention until the bitter end.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: More than anything, this wiry thriller works as a homage to the neo-noir genre.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Despite good performances and an interesting milieu, The Wedding Guest doesn't deliver as an exciting genre piece or thought-provoking drama. Michael Winterbottom is a master in many areas but the thriller seems beyond him this time.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: The Wedding Guest has all the right pieces there but fails to pull together into quite the finished product the high standards of its individual components suggest.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Depending on your expectations, this deliberately slow-paced thriller might serve as a satisfying "I do" or a disappointing "I don't"

title: The Wedding Guest
review: While Dev Patel brings the best performance possible given what he had to work with, it's hard to feel empathy or root for any characters in a story that never really knows what it wants to be.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: Patel works harder to hide his sex appeal in The Wedding Guest than the director does to make it an enticing film.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: The film works surprisingly well.

title: The Wedding Guest
review: A thriller that ambles along when it's supposed to be antic, that takes too many shortcuts in plot and character development.

title: The Intruder
review: The script itself is as paint-by-numbers as you would expect, but it is the characters that turn this film into the so-bad-it's-amazing classic it deserves to become.

title: The Intruder
review: It's hard to narrow down if it's the acting that was terrible or if the dialogue was too bad to act. Likely, it was both.

title: The Intruder
review: It's fun! Is it brilliant or groundbreaking? No.

title: The Intruder
review: A dozen years into his career as a feature filmmaker, Taylor appears to be hitting his stride with The Intruder...

title: The Intruder
review: What makes The Intruder a sad movie is that it feels like a waste of characters and money. [Full review in Spanish].

title: The Intruder
review: Worse still, any attempts at old-school suspense are crassly undermined by gratuitously gruesome scenes of violence and torture that are more suited to full-gore horror of the Saw franchise.

title: The Intruder
review: An inert thriller.

title: The Intruder
review: The Intruder, from its hokey title to its predictable denouement, is the very definition of cookie-cutter modern thriller moviemaking, passing the time but you really wouldn't want it in your house.

title: The Intruder
review: There is gargantuan amounts of fun to be had with The Intruder if you're a fan of agreeably silly thrillers, and, frankly, Dennis Quaid's awards-worthy scenery-chewing is worth the price of admission alone.

title: The Intruder
review: Despite a hot-button topic, The Intruder's tendency toward exploitation and tin ear for racial politics makes it one to avoid.

title: The Intruder
review: I like The Intruder much more as a comedy. Invite all your friends, grab some drinks and you'll have a blast.

title: The Intruder
review: Dennis Quaid goes enjoyably psycho in 'The Intruder'

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Great action with amazing fights will put you in a mood to go and watch hours and hours of Kung fu movies and is a great bridge for franchising Ip Man into a global franchise.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Master Z features a handful of brawls that are each worth the price of admission.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: The plentiful fight scenes are executed with precision and the occasional "wire-fu" flourish by legendary action director Yuen Wo-Ping, with a showdown between gun and wing-chun fist among the more inventive touches.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: The film manages to honor the original series' setting and themes while delivering a completely different type of martial arts film that is wholly entertaining all by itself.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Master Z stretches the limits of how far out one can franchise a biographical film before it devolves into fan fiction.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Elaborate sets that re-create a neon-drenched 1960s Hong Kong make the movie look like someone took Francis Ford Coppola's candy-colored musical flop "One From the Heart" and turned it into a kung fu thriller.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Not bad. What's next in the endless stream of Ip Man movies? Probably in the next Matrix, Ip Man teaches Keanu Reeves's Neo, who will then come out of his trance state and proclaim, "I know better kung fu."

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: My expectations might not have been exceeded in any way, but they were solidly met. I'd happily revisit another one of these tangential adventures in the future.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: This is old-fashioned, silver-screen entertainment, and it's refreshing to watch.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: A rarity as a spin-off from a successful (and still active) action franchise, but it succeeds beautifully as a standalone deserving to spawn some sequels of its own.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: What could have been a feeble attempt to ride on the coattails of Donnie Yen's franchise turns out to be an exhilarating, tightly paced, expertly-crafted martial arts romp.

title: Master Z: Ip Man Legacy
review: Director Woo-Ping Yuen and producers Donnie Yen and Dave Bautista, who also appears in the film, along with legendary Michelle Yeoh, give this martial arts a lot of class.

title: Blood Paradise

review: Ah, the London Blitz. Bombs falling, buildings on fire, people dying all around. Good times, good times.

title: The Edge of Love
review: Unfortunately, like the murky visuals, the story is also muddled.

title: The Edge of Love
review: A bit too arty and concerned with quasi-historical detail to catch fire as a romance (doomed or otherwise), and too yawningly familiar in its major chord plotting to set sail as a honest character ensemble.

review: While all the pieces are there for an intriguing film, John Maybury's The Edge of Love never really becomes anything.
