review: Quote not available.

title: Phil
review: Tired and unconvincing middle-brow sitcom-like dramedy.

title: Phil
review: Greg Kinnear directs himself as a dentist with suicidal tendencies in a bizarre dark comedy. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.

title: Phil
review: This dramedy (Kinnear's directing debut) has its touching, thoughtful moments, but mostly it relies on a creaky old sitcom-like "lie" plot that douses nearly every potential laugh.

title: Phil
review: A clunky an contrived misfire. Even the charismatic Greg Kinnear can't rise above its inane screenplay.

title: Phil
review: Dramedy about a depressed middle-ager tries to unravel the mysteries of life.

title: Phil
review: Phil manages to answer a lot of pertinent philosophical and psychological questions while also being ridiculously funny and not without a small fragment of hope.

title: Phil
review: The film wants to aimlessly pander to the opposing sides of levity and heartbreak but fails to instill any genuine ingredients of grief, sorrow or reflection to go along with its weakened naughty streak of wit.

title: Phil
review: ... manages some moments of emotional honesty about starting over, although it sidesteps the creepy nature of Phil's scheme, preferring to pass off his actions as quirky charm.

title: Phil
review: [T]he story is an aggressively lazy situational comedy.

title: Phil
review: If not for Mazur's script dropping the ball, this might have been just worthy of a mild recommendation. Kinnear, however has a future behind the camera if he wants it.

title: Phil
review: It's not without some charms, but the effort doesn't ring with invention, as Kinnear plays it all too safe to protect himself.

title: Phil
review: Mazur's gimmicky script isn't up to the level of the acting, which carries the picture despite the wobbly comedy-tragedy tightrope Mazur makes the talented cast walk.

title: Ophelia
review: With time, Ophelia will reveal itself as this generation's Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves: lovingly crafted medieval pulp that speaks most eloquently to teenagers, and is enjoyed as high camp by everyone else.

title: Ophelia
review: A stunning reinvention of the tale of Hamlet, thanks to Daisy Ridley's layered performance.

title: Ophelia
review: Redeemed by its conclusion, Ophelia is a lopsided but well-intentioned movie which lost its way when it lost focus on its source material's original audience.

title: Ophelia
review: If you put Shakespeare out of your mind, the film's soapy approach offers some lively moments.

title: Ophelia
review: As a partner piece to Hamlet, it's an interesting twist on the traditional roles. As a standalone film, it somewhat suffers from its parent script. But particularly strong performances and beautiful imagery make it worth catching.

title: Ophelia
review: An interesting, well played and well made attempt to reframe Shakespeare's most famous play through a feminist lens, Ophelia ultimately doesn't have the boldness to deliver on its resonant idea.

title: Ophelia
review: Richly coloured and interestingly flawed, director Claire McCarthy's melodrama is an increasingly bonkers watch, anchored by [Daisy] Ridley's magnetic turn as the passionately conflicted Ophelia.

title: Ophelia
review: While it never quite escapes the soft-focus YA roots of Lisa Klein's source novel, McCarthy breathes vigorous new life into an age-old tale.

title: Ophelia
review: It looks beautiful and is engaging... A clever reimagining.

title: Ophelia
review: The inventions and imaginations are a product primarily of the story and not of the visuals.

title: Ophelia
review: Many Hamlet-lovers will scoff, while for those unfamiliar with the tale, it will make little sense.

title: Ophelia
review: The first casualty is Shakespeare's richness of language, which was obviously judged too complicated to be imposed upon a generation brought up on social media.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Alita belongs in the pantheon of great visual spectacle, gonzo sci-fi cult movies with The Fifth Element, Dark City and Speed Racer.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Yes, I am giving Alita: Battle Angel one of my stingy 10's out of a possible 10. Imaginative, true to the artists' concepts, and an all-out cinematic action blast.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: "Alita: Battle Angel" is a great action scifi/anime adaptation, that is bound to satisfy all fans of the genre.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Ghost in the Shell covered similar thematic territory, but Alita is superior in every way.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Overall, Alita: Battle Angel looks great but the overly sentimental script and uneven character development come across as a rushed mess.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: I enjoyed this far more than I predicted and it's most certainly a big screen experience.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Alita: Battle Angel has incredibly stunning visuals, action, and effects, but the story is far too cramped and feels like several movies stuffed into one.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: A franchise starter that looks nice but lacks humanity

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: The world is fantastically realized. From the costumes to the production design to the character design, every detail feels perfectly drawn out.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Alita: Battle Angel is worth your penny if you are looking for a good, action-packed, entertaining spectacle.

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Great acton, a great cast, a great lead character, and a very intriguing world

title: Alita: Battle Angel
review: Rosa Salazar is more than believable as the innocent, wide-eyed (literally and figuratively) cyborg who eventually discovers she is a fierce warrior.

title: Euphoria
review: It's not that Euphoria lacks good intentions or comes off as superficial in its treatment of death and dying. It's just that there's so much potential for grace or humor or despair or horror inherent in its premise.

title: Euphoria
review: Euphoria would have done better to confront and embrace the challenge of an agnostic argument for euthanasia, and there is certainly one to make. Instead, the movie presents its talking points like a checklist.

title: Euphoria
review: A solemn, heavy-going and foolish drama.

title: Euphoria
review: It's a slow-burn drama that lives in the subtext, which is quietly expressed in the actors' eyes. So watching it requires patience.

title: Euphoria
review: [The] superlative performances from Vikander and Green anchor the proceedings in intimately naturalistic substance that's achingly authentic.

title: Euphoria
review: Moviegoers can feel the pain of the characters, and not in a good way, in this mournful drama that squanders a first-rate cast.

title: Euphoria
review: [T]he movie finds ways to inject superficial, artificial conflict into what could be a thoughtful examination...

title: Euphoria
review: Euphoria induces anything but.

title: Euphoria
review: Langseth doesn't pull any punches with the material, retaining rawness and confusion as emotional breakthroughs are squeezed out of the characters.

title: Euphoria
review: To die or not to die that is the question, And though it is well acted the whole thing is pretty depressing

title: Euphoria
review: The variety of experience portrayed in "Euphoria" continually tickles the cerebrum as the unique atmosphere forces the guests to engage with both the environment and each other, but it's the raw, unvarnished performances that tug at the heart.

title: Euphoria
review: Euphoria is undeniably a missed opportunity at creating a drama of frayed sisterhood that feels fresh and unique.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: A kind romance with a stellar turn by Ellen Page

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Heady problems put the characters in My Days of Mercy through the wringer, but the clarity with which they are captured makes the difficult journey more poignant.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Mixing a death-penalty melodrama and a lesbian romance isn't as awkward as it might seem, thanks mostly to two committed performances and an avoidance of heavy-handed contrivances.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: ...My Days of Mercy clears its biggest hurdle of navigating a lesbian romance and capital punishment.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Mostly about watching Page and Mara manage dramatics, trying to make potentially one-dimensional characters into living, breathing human beings. They're successful, even when the movie isn't.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Beautifully incisive performances by Ellen Page and Kate Mara create a prism through which to examine how the death penalty impacts those far beyond death row. Hardly subtle, and yet still delicate.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Ellen Page, a decade on from her star-making turn in Juno, thrives in a demanding dramatic role as the middle one of three working-class siblings who travel to executions across the US in order to protest against judicial killing.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Contrived yet interesting and undeniably erotic, it's a queer story in both senses.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Despite having a hugely contentious issue at the heart of its plot, this film remains remarkably centred on its characters, all of whom are played with an earthy authenticity that often feels improvised.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: A triumphant female-led film, Mercy soars on the weight of its triptych of great performances, but isn't ballsy enough with its provocative premise.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: Despite the peculiarity of mixing and issue-oriented political film with an LGBT coming-of-age story, it is ultimately a very powerful, emotional, and universal story.

title: My Days of Mercy
review: A horror movie and a love story in its own right, My Days of Mercy is a new take on an old but pressing issue, rooted more in deeply emotions than philosophical arguments.

title: Hellboy
review: The one thing Hellboy has going for it, is that it's never boring. Trainwrecks tend to hold your attention that way.

title: Hellboy
review: [T]he whole piece is like its eponymous character - chaotic, senseless and without direction.

title: Hellboy
review: Everything seemed forced -- certainly the language, the jokes, and especially the gore.

title: Hellboy
review: Yeah, this is terrible.

title: Hellboy
review: The dynamic between [Ian] McShane and [David] Harbour is the beating heart of this new Hellboy.

title: Hellboy
review: The performances are flat, the music is this weird blend of copyrighted songs and generic rock music, and the story is written in a way that prioritizes lengthy redundant talking over providing something amusing for its audience. Hellboy is just boring.

title: Hellboy
review: The pacing is far too quick, yet the movie's runtime comes in over two hours. Hellboy overcomplicates a fairly straightforward story in the process.

title: Hellboy
review: It's a depressing testament to the superhero economy that there's already a reboot of the Hellboy, franchise.

title: Hellboy
review: If you like gory action shlock, you should give it a try!

title: Hellboy
review: Hellboy is a messy, awkwardly vulgar, macabre adventure that can't decide how campy to be, which is ultimately far more entertaining than many self-assured, boring blockbusters.

title: Hellboy
review: For all of its shortcomings -- like weak script and editing -- Hellboy manages to provide a fun experience full of bizarre fights and action that you won't get anywhere else. In a world of comic-book content, it stands out, for better or worse.

title: Hellboy
review: The film takes some familiar genre elements and mixes them up a little, delivering something that feels fresh, occasionally subversive yet -- at times -- as moving as it is outrageous. It's a comedy with plenty of smarts.

title: Pet Sematary
review: Pet Sematary is a mechanically sound, if not entirely scary piece of storytelling.

title: Pet Sematary
review: By building familiar scary imagery atop unceasing adult fears, Pet Sematary captures pragmatic, unshakable panic like a firm gut check.

title: Pet Sematary
review: Pet Sematary is a perfectly functional little horror movie. It doesn't truck in '80s nostalgia, and its significant changes to the source material mostly turn out to be improvements.

title: Pet Sematary
review: Pet Sematary is so engrossed in its own self importance and supposed deeper meaning it forgets to frighten us, or even give us a reason to care in the first place.

title: Pet Sematary
review: An enjoyable but innocuous genre exercise which mostly misses the book's emotional weight.

title: Pet Sematary
review: The 2019 version of Pet Sematary is enough like the original, and enough of it's own thing, to make it more than worth a watch for horror fans!

title: Pet Sematary
review: Pet Sematary has solid scares and performances, but never manages to reach greatness the way other recent Stephen King adaptations have.

title: Pet Sematary
review: This remake resurrects the spirit of Stephen King's and Mary Lambert's originals, while still coming out different.

title: Pet Sematary
review: The new directors (Kevin Kölsch and Dennis Widmyer) and screenwriter (Jeff Buhler) don't hesitate to alter King's original story to make it work as a movie. I applaud this.

title: Pet Sematary
review: A tauter, more crisply paced and psychologically weightier exercise in reanimating the dead in soil turned sour.

title: Pet Sematary
review: The very definition of a useless movie. This lacks any intention of being valid in a sea of remakes. [Full review in Spanish].

title: Pet Sematary
review: Most will find it somewhere between "OK" and "thoroughly good-enough."

title: Styx
review: In a drifting mise-en-scène, the film represents its topical subject matter -- the plight of migrants -- as a timeless crisis of separation, and, for its protagonist, a bitter loss of innocence.

title: Styx
review: The film places what we should have sworn to each other front & centre, and whether we have moved away from simple human compassion in the face of geopolitical hurdles. STYX strips that away to present a drama that is as contemplative as it is engrossing.

title: Styx
review: The ending didn't exceed expectations, but this was a piercingly realistic cinematic experience based on an outrageous true story.

title: Styx
review: It's the refugee crisis in microcosm, and Wolfgang Fischer's movie finds tense ways to create action and complicate the state of play. Still, I'd have preferred a final act that turned this problem-pondering drama into a full-blown thriller.

title: Styx
review: A truly gripping journey into fear, whose questions about personal responsibility linger long after the closing credits.

title: Styx
review: Styx is a gripping sea adventure that mixes thrills and spills with thoughtfulness and compassion.

title: Styx
review: If the metaphors for current refugee policies are sometimes heavy-handed, this response's angry despair is powerfully put.

title: Styx
review: The economy with which Fisher tells us all this is impressive with a map here and a book spine there telling most of the story.

title: Styx
review: Fischer's second feature is so minimalist it makes JC Chandor man-in-a-boat survival drama All is Lost look like Waterworld.

title: Styx
review: A foreboding drama which attempts to scrutinise Western bureaucracy and attitudes towards refugees and, for the most part, succeeds.

title: Styx
review: A work of high drama that is superbly executed. Through a measure of suggestive narrative guile, the film cannot help but make us think about the plight of refugees who risk it all in the Atlantic to try and get to Europe.

title: Styx
review: Great stuff.

title: Transit
review: Phenomenal as an intellectual exercise, a piece of storytelling, a dive into a mysterious, dream-like world, and as a Kafkaesque character drama.

title: Transit
review: Transit is a thrilling and unsettling film that tangibly recreates a nightmare of displacement and uncertainty, but in such a way that could appeal to a broader audience.

title: Transit
review: Christian Petzold's white-hot existentialist noir Transit is perhaps the best World War II film since Paul Verhoeven's Black Book, even if it hinges on a suspension of disbelief that'll be too far a stretch for some.

title: Transit
review: These two actors mesh well together, effortlessly generating a compelling chemistry borne of a shared sense of unease and immediacy.

title: Transit
review: [A] bold adaptation.

title: Transit
review: Lifting the story out of context in this way works in Petzold's favor, as Transit exists as neither a museum piece nor a harrowing depiction of the current refugee crisis, but rather a literary tale of displacement, identity, and seeking.

title: Transit
review: An interesting, if not completely satisfying, drama.

title: Transit
review: For a film based around a lie, Transit has a strong narrative foundation, however, the indistinguishable time period, along with other questionable directorial choices, play too melodramatic to be memorable.

title: Transit
review: Transit captures the tragedy of uncertainty in astonishingly heartbreaking ways.

title: Transit
review: Inhabiting a realm between the past and present, Europe and America, and also cinema and literature, [Petzold's characters] are, in Hannah Arendt's phrase, "living ghosts among the ruins of our times."

title: Transit
review: Playing out as if Michael Curtiz's Casablanca and Michelangelo Antonioni's The Passenger had been re-imagined by Franz Kafka, this adaptation of Anna Seghers's 1942 novel strikingly relocates the action to a millennial Marseilles.

title: Transit
review: [Director Christian] Petzold's best move in Transit is displacing us in time.

title: High Life
review: HIGH LIFE is a story so simple it loops back to the profound and so focused on its characters it collapses through the event horizon to feel universal.

title: High Life
review: High Life is just the right kind of gradual sci-fi film we need, interweaving reality and the truth of our fragility with the fragmented solitude of space.

title: High Life
review: It's an interesting premise, but the structural flaws and unlikable screenplay put to waste the attractive production design.

title: High Life
review: It has the moody flavor of some "existential" '70s-era sci-fi dramas like Tarkovsky's Solaris or Douglas Trumbull's Silent Running, but with a more overtly sexual tone and with lovely, old-school special effects. I just wish it was more fun.

title: High Life
review: Every film by French master Claire Denis is a cultural event, and this, her English-language debut, is a demented, deeply engrossing sci-fi saga...

title: High Life
review: Denis explores the microcosm of life in space, raising uneasy, even queasy questions about humanity's need to push into that frontier, and the costs that will have to be born by individuals.

title: High Life
review: High Life's messages are often too torn apart and deconstructed to keep proper track of, as the movie assaults you with its graphic depictions of all kinds of horrific but believable violence.

title: High Life
review: With its grandiose imagery, devastating themes and philosophy, and complex storytelling, it's a rare hard sci-fi treat, and one that deserves appreciation while playing on the big screen.

title: High Life
review: There is much of Tarkovsky's Solaris in the main body and the flashbacks... could be lifted straight from the same director's Stalker. High Life is, however, stuffed with Denis' characteristic philosophical derangement.

title: High Life
review: At times, it's a kind of space-opera "Suspiria." The brain teasing "Interstellar" is child's play next to Denis' despairing existential black hole.

title: High Life
review: Claire Denis shows crises, confrontations, madness and sex without regard and without fear, knowing how to guage when her story should be excessive and when to cease contemplation. [Full review in Spanish]

title: High Life
review: If you put Ridley Scott's Alien into an airlock, sucked out all the action and excitement, and threw in wobbly sets and Ballardian dialogue enlarging on the "ideas", you might get something close to Claire Denis's High Life.

title: Breakthrough
review: This is a lot better crafted, acted, and has a better cast than a lot of these kinds of films ordinarily do.

title: Breakthrough
review: Here is another illustration of how the faith-based drama has pushed into cinemas material indistinguishable from vast swathes of the afternoon TV schedule.

title: Breakthrough
review: Another glib and unconvincing faith-based movie that pushes miracles, spirituality and divine intervention, hoping for box-office gold. A terrific cast is the only thing that saves it from last rites.

title: Breakthrough
review: one of the more authentically moving entries in the genre, fueled by a gripping lead performance from "This Is Us" star Chrissy Metz.

title: Breakthrough
review: It's a harrowing tale that deserves a much better movie than this insipid junk.

title: Breakthrough
review: A mostly preachy but occasionally compelling dramatization of a true story.

title: Breakthrough
review: Sure, it gets a little bit melodramatic here and there, but what's a good family drama without a little cheese?

title: Breakthrough
review: Although some of the film's moment are reminiscent of a Hallmark movie...its good intentions balance out the cringe-worthy.

title: Breakthrough
review: This brand of lazy, simple-minded propaganda is long past its sell-by date, and Breakthrough does next to nothing to break out of that cycle.

title: Breakthrough
review: There is literally one moment in which it raises an interesting theological problem, then goes right back to what it was doing before...a movie designed to preach to the choir.

title: Breakthrough
review: This Is Us regular Chrissy Metz makes her presence felt as the boy's mum, and Topher Grace and Josh Lucas bring modest star power to a slick if sometimes slushy against-the-odds drama that's perfectly watchable, whether you subscribe to its claims or not.

title: Breakthrough
review: A bold tale of faith is lifted by some decent performances, however the inert narrative breaks the spell.

title: Missing Link
review: The film is sophisticated in its revisionist take on the adventure genre, introducing social and ecological concerns into the mix, though its irreverent humor is still accessible to children.

title: Missing Link
review: The pieces are all there... [but] I kind of would have preferred to watch the making of the movie than the actual movie.

title: Missing Link
review: Stick around for the end credits to get a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the heroes' elephant ride across India. The animators particularly strive to offer a fresh take on their final destination...

title: Missing Link
review: Amid the noisy, epic action of most kid-oriented features, this film's story is clear and effective: a sweet-hearted narrative of how friendship can broaden one's horizons.

title: Missing Link
review: Although it might sound like a lost web address to today's computer-savvy youth, Missing Link is a delightful and polished stop-motion adventure-comedy and droll comment on colonialism.

title: Missing Link
review: The minute details of the stop-motion animation make "Missing Link" come alive, but Laika films need to let their freak flag fly. "Missing Link" is only at half-staff.

title: Missing Link
review: Missing Link manages to impress with its gorgeous animation style, terrific voice performances, and exciting action sequences.

title: Missing Link
review: This movie has the distinctive Laika style, but the characters are not as ugly as previous Laika characters in ParaNorman, or The Boxtrolls. It is funny and easy-going. There is a moral to the story, which comes to a satisfactory conclusion.

title: Missing Link
review: If only the other elements of Missing Link were as strong as the visuals, we'd have a masterpiece on our hands.

title: Missing Link
review: Even a lesser Laika outing is better than what half of Hollywood is making.

title: Missing Link
review: An underrated delightful romp, "Missing Link" takes a conventional adventure story and infuses it with a progressive ethos.

title: Missing Link
review: What really makes the film is the delightful stop-motion animation by Laika studios, which adds a great deal to characters and action sequences alike.

title: The Public
review: A mix of eloquence and satire, in this homeless mass uprising takeover of one of the last remaining US sanctuaries for bookworms and the homeless alike, the public library.

title: The Public
review: The Public presents a heartening story of triumph of good over evil, but sadly lacks the gravitas one would usually expect from these types of stories.

title: The Public
review: Credit to Estevez for making this but it's quite thin, offers no real solutions and has tired characterisations.

title: The Public
review: It's all a bit old-fashioned and earnest but with US civil liberties under attack, it's a timely celebration of humanity.

title: The Public
review: At times feels a worthy successor to the social issue dramas that were a trademark of Stanley Kramer in the civil rights era.

title: The Public
review: The canvas is broad, with lots of supporting characters and subplots, and while the writing is heavy-handed at times in the Golden Age of Television style, Estevez imbues the movie with a large and generous heart.

title: The Public
review: Yes, it's earnest and it tries a little too hard, but it sucked me in.

title: The Public
review: Well-acted but preachy, sometimes corny civics lesson melodrama that's just touching enough and funny enough to come off.

title: The Public
review: There is something decidedly old-fashioned about the storytelling in The Public, but maybe there's truth to the idea that we need to understand and appreciate the past if we're ever going to be able to move forward together.

title: The Public
review: Written, directed by and starring Emilio Estevez, The Public is a pleasantly old-fashioned crowd-pleaser, which argues that libraries are the last great bastion of modern democracy, since they provide free access to knowledge, community and shelter.

title: The Public
review: It's a beautifully shot and directed film that openly wears its heart on its sleeve as an ode to one of the last surviving bastions of free information and public space - the public library.

title: The Public
review: Leaving you with something to think about as you leave the cinema, The Public is both entertaining and informative.

title: After
review: The key to the book's success lies in its artful amateurism. It replicates the tone of one teen confiding in another and in this anodyne screen translation, its intimacy is lost.

title: After
review: The real problem with After is that it's a lifeless slog of thinly written clichés, one that's missing the charismatic spark of the actual One Direction boys.

title: After
review: Come back, Twilight, all is forgiven.

title: After
review: The kind of dispiriting effort that thinks it's scratching an itch for masochistic young girls, but primarily suggests that romance, desire and sexuality aren't worth genuinely exploring.

title: After
review: The problems may lie in Todd's novel, but regardless, characters act illogically, as though written by someone who napped through most of Intro to Psych and skipped English 101 altogether.

title: After
review: After opens with some narration about how certain moments in life seem to define a person, and from there, the clichés pretty much don't stop.

title: After
review: Of such deficient quality that it's unfathomable people will actually pay for a ticket to see this.

title: After
review: The music is fun and the scenery is beautifully cinematic, in a way, but the story itself is neither.

title: After
review: The leads give it all they've got, and Australian actress Josephine Langford is impressive given the limited range of her role. The film looks pretty and director Jenny Gage, to her credit, knows the rhythms of teen melodrama well.

title: After
review: It's a movie well made for its target audience.

title: After
review: After makes 50 Shades Of Grey look like Anna Karenina.

title: After
review: The film's illogical choices and standard teen romance mentality mean nothing that transpires on screen feels remotely fresh.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: It has the same problem I have with most advocacy cinema, regardless of the message, which is that it ultimately winds up one-sided, propagandistic, and perhaps counterproductive.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: Director Vlada Knowlton focuses on her home of Washington State which... allows for an interesting point of entry that is both regional specific and grassroots with nonetheless national connotations.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: Affecting documentary speaks up for trans kids.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: Through her daughter's story, Knowlton illustrates why it's so important that lawmakers protect transgender children's rights.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: [Vlada] Knowlton's feature couldn't be more timely or essential.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: Better at personalizing the experiences and concerns of transgender kids and parents than at documenting the political fight over the "bathroom bill" craze.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: The Most Dangerous Year excels in doing what great politically-charged pieces of art often do. (Director Vlada) Knowlton centers us, grabs our focus, and makes us listen.

title: The Most Dangerous Year
review: Capturing the perspective from families with transgender children, The Most Dangerous Year is a compelling documentary showing that transgender rights matter.

title: Skin in the Game
review: They show us all these really salacious scenes... With a bunch of bad dialogue.

title: Skin in the Game
review: Despite all its cinematic faults, I'm willing to give it a pass because it covers an important topic that is not getting enough attention in the mainstream news.

title: Skin in the Game
review: Based on true events this movie held my attention all the way through till the end. Erica Ash gives a dynamic performance.

title: Skin in the Game
review: A sobering portrait of human trafficking for sex in suburban United States.

title: Crown and Anchor
review: Michael Rowe and Matt Wells give standout performances as cousins who live two separate types of lives. A gritty and entertaining movie about the mean streets of Canada.

title: Crown and Anchor
review: It's a commendable directorial debut for Andrew Rowe who allows the camera and his actors' presence to do a lot of the work. It could have easily been overdone, but his deft writing and directing did a powerful story justice.

title: Crown and Anchor
review: While you can pretty much tell where Crown And Anchor is going from the first scenes, it plays out with power and purpose.

title: Crown and Anchor
review: Even with its nagging, lumbering elements, Crown and Anchor succeeds in taking a hard look on the how our childhoods turn us into the misfit adults we are, and not to find answers, but to simply (and starkly) observe the effects.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: Instead of three-dimensional characters, The Best of Enemies gives us two wax figures in a cardboard town, and they're all at the mercy of Bissel as a writer/director.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: Another movie where black people have the burden of making racists understand they are human beings.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: You know how this movie will play out, but it's educational.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: [It's] staggeringly lengthy and even though this is a true story, the film lacks imagination.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: At a horrific point in U.S. history, The Best of Enemies is accomplished enough to allow its humanist message to shine through without any interference.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: By acutely observing the process, by letting each compromise sink in for the character, and for us, it becomes a kind of catharsis for the characters as they find their way, and for us to hope for the better angels of everyone's nature.

title: The Best of Enemies
review: Takes a micro rather than a macro look at racism in America, (but) avoids many of the pitfalls that Green Book fell into.

title: The Best of Enemies

title: The Quiet One

title: Fighting with My Family
review: As the movie progresses it brings up issues such as body image, sibling rivalry and what it means to be a woman in the public eye, so even if wrestling is not your thing there may be something in the movie that strikes a chord.

title: Fighting with My Family
review: Strong support from parents Nick Frost and Lena Headey add to the slick package of killer one-liners, ace fight fiction and emotional poignancy.

title: Fighting with My Family
review: It's a pleasant enough comedy, even if the outcome is never in doubt. The WWE doesn't make movies about candidates who wash out, after all.

title: Fighting with My Family
review: Fighting with My Family won't stay with you because it's brilliant or subversive, but it's fun to watch. It'll make you laugh, it might make you cry, and you get to root for the characters and leave the theater feeling good.

title: Fighting with My Family
review: Above all else, the film is surprising and appealing at every level, and if you think this is a story you wouldn't care about in a million years, then it's especially built for you.

title: Fighting with My Family
review: A charm all of its own and a heart as big as The Rock's biceps...

title: Fighting with My Family
review: Thoroughly accessible for non-wrestling fans out there and the kind of family sports flick that makes you feel all gushy afterwards

title: Mosul
review: [E]mbedded Iraqi journalist Ali Maula acts as our guide and his musings on the situation in his homeland give this film an editorial and contextual anchor that will help viewers less familiar with the day-to-day socio-politics of Iraq.

title: Mosul
review: It is harrowing, but if you can stomach it, it's an extraordinary thing to sit through.

title: Mosul
review: Mosul thrusts the audience into its world with unwavering relentlessness while allowing ample time to reflect. Gritty, powerful and honest, the film begs to be experienced, discussed, and remembered.

title: Mosul
review: The powerful documentary is comprised of combat footage and raw interviews taken by Iraqi journalist, Ali Maula from October 2016 to August 2017.

title: Blaze
review: More than a biography about a cursed aura composer and performer, Blaze is a love song to the country & western. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Blaze

title: Blaze
review: Hawke pieces together an impressive and thought-provoking tribute with a Texas-sized heart and the kind of performances that awards are made for. Even when you know what's coming, Blaze haunts you like a classic country song.

title: Blaze
review: It's a lengthy, inebriating, and casually funny experience that didn't fall into the usual traps of biographical films.

title: Blaze
review: An affectionate, honest portrait that interrogates our need to deify dead icons, while carving out a space in music history long left vacant for Foley to fill.

title: Blaze
review: A songwriter making his major acting debut, Dickey captures the burly, vulnerable quality of Foley's lyrics and vocal delivery, creating a palpable sense that the songs were excavated from the darkest corners of his soul.

title: Blaze
review: Even as a viewer not knowing much about Foley, watching Dickey makes one feel that you are watching the actual man -- he's that natural in the role.

title: Blaze
review: A quietly mournful and gently celebratory look at a boisterous, but underrated personality, Ethan Hawke's biopic Blaze is a humane approach to creating iconography organically and empathetically.

title: Blaze
review: Beautifully shot, this low-key life story feels at times like you're flipping through an old album, crammed with artfully arranged memories and aphorisms.

title: Blaze
review: Blaze might be telling a story we've seen before, but it does so from an angle that offers a few surprises.

title: Blaze
review: People who knew him said he gave off so much menace, he scared bikers. This is a film about a big drunk lovable, doomed song-writing Teddy bear who happens to be named Blaze Foley.

title: Blaze
review: Blaze's methods are more poetic than proclamatory, focused primarily on transforming the raw facts of Blaze Foley's life into an elliptical and heartsick dive bar epic.

title: See You Yesterday

title: See You Yesterday

title: See You Yesterday
review: A heady mix of clever plotting, sharp street humour, phat reggae beats and an emotional gut punch to rival recent cinema releases Blackkklansman or Detroit.

title: See You Yesterday
review: With impeccable, emotional acting from Smith and scenes that may be difficult for viewers to watch, See You Yesterday starts out feeling lighthearted, fun and real.

title: See You Yesterday

title: See You Yesterday
review: The film's rumination on grief does not always pair seamlessly with its spitfire teen comedy half but Bristol's debut film is all the more gnarly and compelling for this lack of seamlessness.

title: See You Yesterday
review: Teens travel back in time; violence, language.

title: See You Yesterday
review: The film's ambiguous ending [is] frustrating but fitting.

title: See You Yesterday
review: Kick back on a night when you're looking for both gravity and glee (emphasis on the gravity), and enjoy.

title: See You Yesterday
review: It gives us a wonderful black female character, the message of both despair and hope, and a story that could easily be continued as a popular Netflix series.

title: See You Yesterday
review: See You Yesterday is a film not to be taken at face value. It is a film that is multi-layered and crafted to deliver each layer in a timely and thought-provoking manner.

title: See You Yesterday
review: See You Yesterday doesn't sacrifice the child-like wonder of adventure for a grounded story. For a film in this genre, the stakes are higher than ever before.

title: Funny Story

title: Funny Story

title: Funny Story

title: Funny Story
review: Matthew Glave shines in Michael J. Gallagher's uneven, but entertaining, dramedy.

title: Funny Story
review: Its attempted transition into a heartfelt tale of inclusion and reconciliation falls flat because the strained screenplay keeps its characters too detached from reality.

title: Funny Story
review: [T]he film begins as a comedy of errors and evolves with the realization that those errors were choices and that choices have consequences.

title: Funny Story

title: Funny Story
review: FUNNY STORY has a few minutes of humor, but it takes more than that to make a "funny story.

title: Funny Story
review: Unfortunately, despite an appealing cast, Gallagher's film falls into old stereotypes because the script simply doesn't dig into the characters or dynamics that he should.

review: Even though there's nothing inherently funny about the main story ... Gallagher and co-writer Steve Greene manage to find humor in the humanity of the characters, brought to life beautifully from the whole cast.

review: Matthew Glave's charm and the script's wit compensate for a screenplay rife with gay stereotypes and cliches.

title: Funny Story
review: Gallagher shows a steady hand and an "acute" understanding of what's unfolding between Walter and Kim, creating a fascinating dynamic where the tension comes from seeing whether the pair can resist pulling others into their path of destruction.

title: Rim of the World

title: Apollo 11

review: The end of the road for Neeson's Man with a grudge action hero.

title: Gloria Bell

title: Gloria Bell
review: Leilo's empathy for his characters is matched by his actors' skills.

title: ANIARA
review: ANIARA does not offer a resolution, nor hope, nor catharsis. The film presents, if anything, a warning: our existence is a universal privilege to cherish, not a selfish entitlement to be hubristically guarded.

title: ANIARA
review: Aniara mostly feels like a dramatization of facts rather than telling a story.

title: ANIARA
review: Although little of this is new, it's delivered with poise and grace, aided by finely tuned performances. Interpersonal dynamics are explored with a light touch but it takes only the slightest deviation to reveal great gulfs of darkness.

title: ANIARA
review: It's an acquired taste and its view on humanity is perhaps blacker than the depths of space, but Aniara is sci-fi of melancholy near-brilliance.

title: ANIARA
review: You start going through all the logistical problems inherent in this scenario... [But] once I was able to get past some of that, then I was able to absorb some of the big existential questions.

title: ANIARA
review: Aniara cogently makes the point that if mankind ever does manage to leave this blighted planet for another, we'll bring our problems with us.

title: ANIARA
review: Aniara is a compelling study of human nature, which never shies away from condemning the ways in which mankind has scuppered its own continued existence, and will continue to do so even when it does consider a move into the stars.

title: ANIARA
review: A haunting allegorical tale, Aniara warns of humanity hurtling in the wrong direction and realising too late that there is no turning back.

title: ANIARA

review: Special effects are used minimally, the directors instead concentrating on the fragile human emotions of the disparate travellers, among whom Jonsson especially impresses.

title: ANIARA
review: A strange and unsettling sci-fi which has a rather bleak outlook on the future of humanity.

title: ANIARA
review: It's terrifying precisely because it looks current rather than space age. We see ourselves reflected more clearly, and don't have the luxury of thinking that a futuristic setting means we have time to spare. Oh and the ending is a belter.

title: Ladies in Black
review: Ladies in Black fits the bill, beautifully.

review: It's a film whose cast is utterly sweet and lovely to look at even if the movie feels incredibly thin.

review: Despite its drawbacks, Ladies in Black is a fun, charismatic tale executed by a talented ensemble clearly delighting in their roles.

review: Corny and old-fashioned, but charming.

title: Ladies in Black
review: The way every ruffle of a dress or lace embellishment is offered a moment and how audiences can admire the pattern of a gown as much as the acting recalls Jocelyn Moorhouse's The Dressmaker...

title: Starfish
review: White's film is interesting and unique with enough tension to keep things moving, but will leave you more confused than enthralled.

review: As strong as White's direction is here, the film doesn't work without the strength of Gardner's performance.

title: Starfish

review: A. T. White's fascinating debut feature isn't exactly hard science fiction, but there's certainly a logic to it. "Starfish" is one strange retro ride.

title: The Perfection
review: Entertaining in a way that's at once showy and rather clinical.

title: The Perfection
review: It is complexly, an emotionally draining, exhilirating, and liberating quest.

title: The Perfection
review: The fact that most of it works pretty well is a happy, bloody, and creepy surprise.

title: The Perfection
review: It's difficult to know when bungled takes are compensated by good enough film-making that the end result is acceptable...

title: The Perfection
review: In its final form, this one-of-a-kind genre Frankenstein is a stand-out terror in an increasingly inventive and competitive field. Controversial, slippery, and sickening, The Perfection will get you screaming, then talking.

title: The Perfection
review: For those who like their films a little darker than mainstream studios are willing to bankroll, The Perfection might be right for you. It's dirty, messy moviemaking with a message.

title: The Perfection
review: As the twists and turns get even more egregious, The Perfection just becomes a chore to watch. It's unfortunate because the final beat is actually chilling and portends what could have been. A lighter touch would have been welcome.

title: Happy Death Day 2U
review: The change in genre is the best twist Landon could take for the franchise, playing to the series' strengths as a lightweight, stylish genre comedy.

title: Happy Death Day 2U
review: Happy Death Day 2U is easily the most fun movie experience I've had in the early part of the 2019 movie year. It has a little bit of something for everyone and is a good Valentine's Day date movie.

review: It's an unwieldy, uncertain monster of a movie, so lacking the first's amiable nimbleness and cheek. Bigger means hollower in this inessential sequel, yet it's still entirely watchable at the worst of times due to Rothe's effervescent presence.

title: Happy Death Day 2U
review: Happy Death 2U answers all of the first film's unanswered questions and has way more fun with its wacky time loop murder concept in an extremely entertaining way.

title: Happy Death Day 2U
review: It's both a fantastic and audacious sequel that is willing to kill its darlings and be different, while simultaneously...well, unfortunately killing its darlings and being completely different.

title: Happy Death Day 2U

title: Wine Country

title: Wine Country
review: Wine Country may not be the movie you expect, but it is pleasant enough reminder to not take life too seriously, let your friends support you, and that sometimes... you need some R&R.

title: Avengement

review: Putting the middle finger to originality, narrative coherence, and deserving humor is Johnson.

review: Technically, Adkins isn't flying around as much as Cain but honestly, he's still so fast that you don't really feel Adkins is holding back.

review: There's really no downside to this continued collaboration and the rate at which it blesses us.

title: Isabelle

title: Isabelle
review: Without a doubt this is the silliest story to be committed to film in recent memory.

review: There are some intriguing, understated ideas floating around under the surface - but the movie keeps shouting its objectives at us.

review: There's some good editing work by Diane Brunjes but the film lapses too easily into cliché, suggesting a lack of confidence in its central vision.

review: The film comes off like a short story expanded but not properly developed to feature length.

title: A Violent Separation
review: "A Violent Separation" doesn't come together tightly, but there's cinematic clarity at times, especially during its more procedural moments.

review: A promising B-movie thriller the filmmakers can never quite bring themselves to edit into this slow, cluttered picture into the lean little neo-noir it wants to be.

title: A Violent Separation
review: The kindest thing that can be said about the movie is that it's a solid PSA to not mess around with firearms like a moron

title: A Violent Separation
review: The morality of the tale isn't really as complex as the filmmakers seem to think and the central characters' struggles seem more a reflection of their personal shortcomings than something that will present a challenge for the viewer.

title: The Professor

title: The Professor

review: Most of the emotion doesn't track as clearly as it should, periodically inspiring Depp to manufacture his own version of the movie with expected exaggeration.

review: This film is an easy target for being misintepreted by those with an axe to grind in the "me too" era; a sadder truth is that its clumsy approach was most likely unintentional.

title: Wanda Sykes: Not Normal

review: In the end, though, when Sykes is her own Last Comic Standing, she turns her comedy lens back onto herself.

title: Wanda Sykes: Not Normal
review: Sykes manages to balance the personal and the political in a way that doesn't feel heavy-handed, even if comedians commenting on Trump has now become de rigueur.

title: Good Sam
review: Bland performances of bland characters in a bland story.

title: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience

review: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience genuinely feels as though it were made especially for me; it is a smart, hilarious piece of work by a remarkably talented trio.

review: It's as hilarious as you can imagine. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience
review: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience is a weird flex, but we'd be more than OK if the Lonely Island gave us more stuff like this, on a streamer that's clearly content to let them do whatever the hell they want.

title: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience
review: In the end, what stands out about the project is not the baseball premise, but the format: the first and best tear-down of the visual album conceit.

review: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers is equally vicious and loving, showing the two athletes as hapless idiots driving by smashing balls and trolling for women.

title: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience
review: In between, dream sequences, short sketches and even spoken word stitch together the music videos into a cohesive throughline. And there are plenty of celebrity guest stars making appearances in those videos.

title: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience
review: If anything, TUBBE exists as a wildcard example of funny dudes making something for shits and guaranteed giggles.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: Gripping, funny, and socially relevant-The Great Buddha+ is worth a watch if you have any interest in Taiwanese society or cinema.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: It's an awkwardly funny and bleak black comedy on unbridled voyeurism that reflects cynically on the human condition.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: It's not often that political and social satire can sleep together in the same cinematic bed, but Huang has found the magic jelly to make his many points convincingly.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: ...an odd, philosophical smorgasbord of scathing themes that colorfully decorate this off-kilter social critique of underclass religion and repression...an ambitious, imaginative, and bitingly humorous cultural concoction of meager existences in Taiwan

title: The Great Buddha+
review: Taiwan's candidate for the U.S. Academy Awards finds comedy amid its serious concern with inequality of income.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: The Great Buddha+ doesn't deliver a satisfying conclusion, which makes the whole film slightly exhausting to watch.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: This compassion allows for a more in-depth connection to the interiority of characters... and elevates the story into a kind of folklore or moral tale.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: The scathing social critique of The Great Buddha + is comparable to that of Marco Ferreri's Spanish black comedies... in which an underclass' universe is portrayed with vitriolic humor mixed with tenderness. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Great Buddha+
review: With The Great Buddha +, Huang Hsin-yao makes a brilliant first impression on the international film scene.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: Viewers looking for renewed faith in the power, vision, and sheer fun of movies will love The Great Buddha +, which manages to dig into particulars of life in Taiwan while stressing odd aspects of modern life almost everyone can relate to.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: Marvelous Taiwanese study of down-and-outers' survival strategies defines "bittersweet," while managing to be effin' hilarious along the way.

title: The Great Buddha+
review: An extended, polite duel of veiled criticism which could be used as part of training programs for diplomats exemplifies what Huang does best: sit back and take pleasure in humans being both ingenious and worthy of laughter.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)

review: Cinematography is so "folktale gorgeous," fully realizing the maddening effects of isolation (much like THE WIND/THE WITCH). A deeply, destructively disturbing taste of pagan witchcraft horrors.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: Fiegelfeld's film looks back at a time when folklore and the supernatural held a stranglehold on people's minds, and how such a punishing religious climate affected women.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: Moody and atmospheric, this German horror film plays on ancient legends as it recounts an old-world tale about a dark curse.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: The tension and sinister omens build almost unbearably. It's a singular tone poem that evokes powerful unease.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: Its greatest achievement is the way Hagazussa becomes more powerfully hallucinatory and yet more bluntly real as it unfolds.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: Though some of it may be a little too stomach-churning for some viewers, Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse is a solid piece of filmmaking and announces Lukas Feigegeld as a name to keep an eye on in the future.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: An art-house nightmare that will linger in your head long after the credits roll.

title: Hagazussa: A Heathen's Curse (Hagazussa)
review: Hagazussa provides a minefield of triggers. It's gross. It's also stunning, a hypnotic recreation of its time and its place.

title: What Men Want

title: What Men Want
review: It's just not as funny, progressive or challenging as the concept - a gender swapped remake of the Mel Gibson starrer What Women Want - would have allowed it to be.

title: What Men Want
review: Works with its tried plot device, resulting in the type of superficially pleasing comedy that audiences will lap up along with their snacks before it fades away with a more substantial meal.

review: A largely thrilling endeavor that'll play well in television reruns, but may never find a stronger audience than that.

review: Interesting, intriguing and different, Destroyer has mystery, action and incredible acting.

review: "You look terrible," her ex-boss tactlessly informs LAPD detective Erin Bell (Nicole Kidman). He's not wrong.

review: Steven Knight's film triggers agitation, frustration and exasperation. Matthew McConaughey does channel his inner-Tommy Wiseau in two scenes, so there's that...

review: Serenity is a film that seems to reject understanding or even reality.

review: Serenity is either incredibly brilliant or monumentally terrible. I'm not sure which.

review: Clammy and claustrophobic, The Things We've Seen can build an effective mood as its characters struggle with problems. Even with a small budget, determined filmmakers can accomplish something worthwhile.

title: Miss Bala

review: This film suffers from its Hollywood-ization... It's all so slick.

review: Catherine Hardwicke distorts the main objectives of Gerardo Naranjo's original film. [Full Review in Spanish]

review: Now, I don't like the cartel sub-genre that has been forming...That being said, I give credit where credit is due...Unfortunately, there isn't much credit due here.

review: The most memorable part of Miss Bala is when "Los Ageless" by St. Vincent plays during a party scene. That rules. The rest of the film, sadly, does not.

review: Aside from a few stylistic choices and an engaging performance from Rodriguez, Miss Bala is a paint-by-numbers crime drama that lacks any real poignancy or cutting commentary.

title: Miss Bala

title: In Search of Greatness
review: In Search of Greatness is extremely watchable and a strong tribute to the athletes at its center.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: In Search of Greatness provides an intriguing look at sporting excellence that should hopefully inspire the next generation to break free from the overly structured thinking that threatens to hold them back.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: In Search of Greatness makes a strong case for intangibles as the decisive factor in sports excellence.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: In Search of Greatness is a fascinating documentary with a ground-breaking message. This is a necessary viewing for anyone interested in sports psychology. Downside: the subjects are overwhelmingly male.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: Polsky's overall playfulness speaks to the truth and honesty at the heart of In Search of Greatness.

title: In Search of Greatness

title: In Search of Greatness
review: Though uneven and at times overstuffed with imagery and generalization, it offers a useful message for obsessive 'sports dads' to hear.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: ... might not be that surprising, but the candidness of the subjects is refreshing.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: A vividly entertaining exploration of developing the best athletes. Ironically, you don't have to be a sports enthusiast to enjoy and glean life-changing information from the film.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: An interesting look at what makes certain athletes so darn good.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: Polsky... consults with experts including Wayne Gretzky, Jerry Rice, and Pele, all of whom are vexed at the current state of things and advocate for a less-structured system that promotes initiative and creativity.

title: In Search of Greatness
review: Sports fans will enjoy the plethora of old sports action and analysis. And, documentary lovers will get something that educates, entertains and gives insight to the history of sports.

title: Charm City
review: Charm City is not only a superb and moving work of non-fiction filmmaking, it is also one of those socially conscious and totally righteous documentaries with the power to help spur reform.

title: Charm City
review: By the end, there's no easy answer for Baltimore's problems. Yet by focusing on real people who are trying to make a difference, Charm City humanizes the city.

title: Charm City
review: Marilyn Ness, who was a producer for the film Cameraperson, takes a fly-on-the-wall approach, but detached she is not.

title: Charm City
review: Charm City hits with the bracingly real force and honesty of Frederick Wiseman film. It's exceptionally well edited, with all three aspects of Baltimore life depicted in both positive and negative lights, but nothing here is being skewed.

title: Charm City
review: With equal doses of hope and despair, this gritty and provocative verite-style documentary chronicles life on the streets of contemporary Baltimore.

title: Charm City
review: ...[a] disturbing and defiant documentary. Thoroughly involving and moving Charm City is both oddly inspirational and nightmarish in its raw presentation. Ness oversees a different kind of horror show...

title: Charm City
review: [Charm City] helps the viewer imagine a future that doesn't require a massive armed police presence to make neighborhoods like Rose Street safer.

title: Charm City
review: Gritty and ultra-real look at the present day inner city. No flinching in this one.

title: Charm City
review: It's a powerful movie ... because it raises a myriad of issues, asks a lot of questions, offers some contrasting opinions, and then lets the viewer decide.

title: Charm City
review: Charm City may not be an easy watch, but [director Marilyn] Ness argues that through empathy, progress can be made.

title: Arctic
review: Mads Mikkelsen shines in this uneven tale of survival that could have used more time in the editing room.

title: Arctic
review: Cerebral in its own way, with a purposely vague story that rewards the thoughtful viewer.

title: Arctic
review: For the most part, this is a typical story of survival in harsh conditions, but there are some plot twists, and it is a well-made film. Mikkelsen shines as the rugged, capable pilot of a downed plane somewhere in the Arctic Circle.

title: Arctic
review: What keeps you watching is Mikkelsen. The actor is at his best in the open air, and here he gives the tundra a run for its money in the competition to see who can seem the most rugged and elemental.

title: Arctic
review: With just a little more invention and originality, this film might have been something truly special. As it stands, it's a fantastic showcase for its star and, though slow in places, still highly watchable.

title: Arctic
review: There's an existential quality to Arctic, a tremendously moving meditation on how we persevere through near-insurmountable hardships, what it takes to keep the light from going out.

title: Arctic
review: A survival story that shifts gears into a spiritual parable about kindness and compassion.

title: Arctic
review: If you like survival epics -- and I happen to love them -- this is one of the very, very best.

title: Arctic
review: This is survivalism stripped down to its bare essence, free of sentimentality, thematic pretensions, and unnecessary narrative devices. Arctic  delivers man-versus-nature conflict at its most elemental.

title: Arctic
review: Arctic is a slow-moving film that focuses on humanity and one man's continuous ambition, hope and perseverance against all of the odds to save himself and another life. Mikkelsen drives this film with another outstanding performance.

title: Arctic
review: It's a tale we've seen before but Mikkelsen imbues it with something entirely new.

title: Arctic
review: By taking the naturalistic approach, Penna manages to do what most first-time directors cannot: show restraint.
