review: There's a refreshing simplicity to this gritty thriller, as filmmaker Matthew Pope uses well-worn but effective cinematic language to build suspense and a strong sense of unease.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Pope, Thompson, and lead actress Lind work together to create a visceral portrait of paranoia and anxiety that draws tension from its exploration of cycles of violence.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: It's flawed, but it's a tightly wound, mournful thriller about a young woman in a very bad situation.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Lind is such a skillful actress that the occasional implausibility and moral ambiguity of Leigh's situation becomes compelling and rather suspenseful.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: This Southern gothic neo-noir (that's a mouthful!) is based on a woman who accidentally kills a man while defending herself. Panicked, she decides to cover up the death.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: ...a good yarn is a good yarn, and the mismatch of the film's various elements can't fully derail the good ideas at play here.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blood On Her Name is alive and invested in its characters so much that it allows them to go where they would for reasons that make sense to them.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blending elements of crime-thriller and revisionist Western, Blood on Her Name delivers a uniquely exciting experience.

title: Ne Zha
review: In some very important ways, it's competing right up to the level of Pixar or Disney themselves.

title: Ne Zha
review: It is not a major achievement in the genre - other than in the commercial sense - but it is a bold and promising step along the road.

title: Ne Zha
review: Ne Zha has some shaky storytelling to begin with, but by the second half, it escalates into a full-fledged emotional animated blockbuster.

title: Ne Zha
review: Ne Zha tells a fantastical story of Gods, power and finding your place in the world no matter who you are. It possesses buckets of charm, chemistry and comedy that places it amongst the elite animated films from across the globe.

title: Ne Zha
review: There are several eye-popping action sequences, and while the final act feels over- indulgent, Ne Zha is still a praiseworthy effort.

title: Ne Zha
review: ...a glorious panorama unto itself.

title: Ne Zha
review: It's very hard to make sense of... [During] a lot of it, you just feel like you're wandering some trackless wilderness.

title: Ne Zha
review: Lots of fantasy violence in animation based on Chinese myth.

title: Ne Zha
review: Strange and funny enough to recommend on its own.

title: Ne Zha
review: Conventionally animated but paced with kinetic glee, Ne Zha crams in a plethora of contemporary and pop culture references, and in those moments it's at its least fun and most obvious.

title: Ne Zha
review: The film remains whimsical and entertaining for adults and children alike, and its treatment of a Chinese folk deity is surprisingly accessible for audiences unfamiliar with Chinese mythology.

title: Bombshell
review: The entertainingly potent Fox News docu-satire, Bombshell, is jammed with incident - largely based on events at the network during the 2015 election cycle - but the film's most unsettling nugget is one that's presented in the first five minutes.

title: Bombshell
review: It's this element of recoil from total sympathy with these harassed women that makes the film intriguing though.

title: Bombshell
review: [A] timely satirical takedown that finds black humour and absurdist comedy in the subject of workplace sexual harassment while never losing sight of its devastating repercussions.

title: Bombshell
review: [Director Jay Roach] and Randolph are rightly fascinated by the social climate and geography of the Fox offices -- the factions, hierarchies, protocols and rivalries that define the place.

title: Bombshell
review: Disingenuous trash.

title: Bombshell
review: Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman, John Lithgow at the top of their game in a solid recap of sexual harassment at Fox News.

title: Bombshell
review: A confused depiction of fact. Great makeup and performances but a disastrous script make this one a disappointing film. [Full review in Spanish].

title: Bombshell
review: While it touches on the toxic masculinity and systematic sexism that permeates Fox News, it does little to contextualize the industry that allowed this behavior to thrive.

title: Bombshell
review: The film wields its arms to signal that its time to step aside and let women take their spots as leads in their own stories. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Bombshell
review: The performances in the film are spot-on, especially Theron as Kelly.

title: Bombshell
review: Theron and Robbie do a lot with characters that, at least on paper, don't appear to be quite three-dimensional. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Bombshell
review: The obsession with real dates... the insistence on resemblance and makeup prostheses, the need for a frantic narrative rhythm... [are] obstacles that endanger the project's original nobility. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Color Out of Space
review: There are messages about the environment, the media and there are lots of laughs, it is quite genre-defying in ways.

title: Color Out of Space
review: The gruesome events and Cage's varied performance (opposite Joely Richardson as his wife) make steady entertainment for fans of weird horror. Given its potential, though, Richard Stanley's film is a touch disappointing.

title: Color Out of Space
review: ... this eldritch tale seems ready-made for a Nic Cage vehicle... a beautiful picture of a descent into madness, an acceptance of inevitability, and a family truly brought together as none have before.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Create a hazy sense of itchy otherworldliness cohabiting with the quotidian space of a rundown farm.

title: Color Out of Space
review: a trippy rainbow of the gory and the grotesque

title: Color Out of Space
review: This sci-fi horror has a superb everyday tone that director-cowriter Richard Stanley cleverly warps into bonkers body snatchers nastiness. Subtle effects and freak-out set-pieces put the audience increasingly on edge.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Befitting the title, Stanley makes a magical use of colour, deep pinks and blues and greens visually stunning and eventually terrifying, before all this saturation and brightness gives way to a climactic explosion of grey.

title: Color Out of Space
review: For Cage completists only.

title: Color Out of Space
review: [A]s the toxic alien presence exerts its grip on the surrounding area, both star and film go properly nuts, with Cage subdued one minute and howling at the moon the next and Stanley's visuals toggling between psychotropic weirdness and outright gore.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Aside from a couple of missteps, the film is endlessly imaginative and, as suits its title, showcases a vibrant visual palette.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Stanley's film is a weird, nasty little treat- climate change horror filled with spacey neon pleasures and proper existential terror.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Color Out of Space is gloriously old school, stomach-churning, rib-tickling and strangely poignant, with warnings about big business and dirty water thrown in amid the gunge.

title: Dark Waters
review: The groundswell of dogged determination propelling this environmental thriller is so powerful that it deals effortlessly with the knotty tangle of facts packed into its plot. Much of this is down to the film's star and initiator, Mark Ruffalo.

title: Dark Waters
review: The subject deserved better.

title: Dark Waters
review: In Dark Waters, [Todd Haynes] bathes his audience in pure terror like very few other directors could.

title: Dark Waters
review: True to its title, this is a murky pool of a movie, and Mark Ruffalo is the man on the bank, poking its surface with a stick.

title: Dark Waters
review: A movie that works marvellously well within its own generic terms...

title: Dark Waters
review: The Bilotts make compelling viewing, straight arrows losing the scales from their eyes.

title: Dark Waters
review: There is, admittedly, a dark fascination in seeing how flagrantly giant companies mess with people's lives. As an expose about corporate malfeasance, Dark Waters is especially topical and timely given the findings of the recent banking inquiry.

title: Dark Waters
review: It's effective rather than exciting and the narrative is more than strong enough to grip the attention even if it is overly long.

title: Dark Waters
review: A fine issues-based affair worthy of comparison to the likes of Silkwood, The Insider and Erin Brockovich.

title: Dark Waters
review: While worthy and important, Dark Waters is a functional, by-numbers legal drama that is illuminating without setting your world alight.

title: Dark Waters
review: They say nothing sticks to Teflon, and in Todd Haynes' corporate conspiracy drama Dark Waters, you'll realise that not much sticks to evil corporations either.

title: Dark Waters
review: That said, the inherent exasperation seems to accurately represent the endless setbacks, obfuscations, and heartaches inherent in fighting for corporate environmental justice.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Shin infuses an intoxicating blend of grime, crime, and style into Disappearance at Clifton Hill, all of which make it a twisted treat to enjoy.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Disappearance at Clifton Hill suffers from an incoherent and uninspired script even if it boasts great performances and stellar technical achievements.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: As an ambiguous look at the nature of truth and deception, Clifton Hill has an unsettling low-key potency, which is why the final third - when the plotting gets strained and Shin wraps things up with a "gotcha" ending - is so disappointing.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: The septuagenarian filmmaker does great supporting work in a film that's otherwise long on atmosphere but short on specifics...

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Earning more points for style than substance, this atmospheric Canadian noir lacks enough tension to sufficiently pay off its titular mystery.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: What sets "Disappearance at Clifton Hill" apart is how quietly menacing it all feels.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Anchored by a solid performance from Middleton, lush production, and solid writing, we have a delicious mystery that confounds as much as it beguiles.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: [Writer-director Albert] Shin's haunting Niagara Noir delivers the chills and a dripping wet David Cronenberg as a grinning Botticelli Venus.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Worth watching for Middleton's compelling central performance, the intricate noirish plot and the well-designed and shot retro locations.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Albert Shin's Disappearance at Clifton Hill is a neo-noir told mainly in nostalgic colors, smoke and mirrors.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Shin and co-screenwriter James Schultz have given us a most unique detective...

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Does so many things right that it's unfortunate that, in the end, it proves a disappointment.

title: The Dark Red
review: Director-cowriter Dan Bush is an assured filmmaker who carefully builds the story using darkly dramatic flashbacks before flipping everything on its head.

title: The Dark Red
review: Twisty psychological thriller.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red isn't afraid to get a little bloody, and it's all the more entertaining for it.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red is an interesting way of exploring the hysterical mother trope. Helped massively by a great lead performance, The Dark Red may just have birthed the next screen Sarah Connor.

title: The Dark Red
review: Dan Bush's The Dark Red is a tale of maternity and madness, vampiric predation and class exploitation.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red is a smart little film with a more sophisticated understanding of its subject matter and more to say than past stories of this sort might lead you to expect.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: [A] brash, crass, often mind-numbing ride.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: A satire of overamped gamer culture that is itself too overamped to be much fun...

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Writer-director Jason Lei Howden's humor might have been tolerable if his film was at least reasonably imaginative.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Anyone with an attention span above ADD levels... is likely to find this undeniably slick, energetic contraption plays somewhere between grating and numbing.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: It's somehow exhausting but not exhilarating, a non-stop chase scene that would be a good deal more fun if not getting caught seemed even like a one-in-a-million prospect.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: The film is a perfect example of a promising concept being ruined by a visually and audibly obnoxious execution. Its nonstop video game references make Guns Akimbo feel like a film that is too aware for its own good.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Restricted to 95 minutes, the film doesn't try to do more than the bizarre premise promises, which is an off-the-wall shoot 'em up featuring a reluctant and ill-qualified hero.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Guns Akimbo is a force to be reckoned with and is a film that can confidently stand alongside early Peter Jackson or Mark L. Lester. Run to see this wild, insane ride.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Writer-director Jason Lei Howden plays even the most grotesquely over-the-top nastiness for laughs, celebrating each moment of death or dismemberment. While some viewers may be appalled by this, fans of trashy carnage will love it.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Frenetic might be an understatement here. Adrenaline rush is delivered as you are watching.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Guns Akimbo is finally a well-directed film, edited with clarity and a keen sense of pacing by the team of Luke Haigh and Zaz Montana.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Has this juvenile, punk rock vibe that mostly works really well-even if it is weirdly juxtaposed with some unnecessary serious comments about how violence actually is "in real life".

title: The Climbers
review: While emphasizing spectacle over substance, this true-life adventure about Chinese mountaineers trying to climb Mount Everest is only sporadically stirring.

title: The Climbers
review: The Climbers had the potential to be a gripping drama-thriller and project China's soft power while doing so, but instead the overt focus on fighting for national pride makes the film a flop.

title: The Climbers
review: This account of the Chinese Mount Everest expeditions in 1960 and 1975 is a nationalistic spectacle that, curiously, often also allows personal sentiment to get in the way of the greater good.

title: Richard Jewell
review: This is, frankly, a political film and it's no secret that Eastwood is not exactly on the left, but, ever the pragmatist, he leaves room for multiple readings.

title: Richard Jewell
review: It's not Eastwood's finest hour.

title: Richard Jewell
review: In many ways, it is a very good story, efficiently told - and that's down to the excellent and very plausible performance from Paul Walter Hauser.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Richard Jewell is pointed and compelling - so much so that it needn't underline its themes as thickly as it does.

title: Richard Jewell
review: In Clint Eastwood's hands, Richard Jewell becomes a martyr to the director's career-long cause: heroism when it exists in direct opposition to authority.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Nothing is accidental in a Clint Eastwood film - such is the shame of Richard Jewell.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Where it falters - and badly - is in its portrayal of real-life reporter Kathy Scruggs. It leaves a bitter taste and mars the whole package, undermining its own good work elsewhere.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Paul Walter Hauser's powerhouse performance firms this tale of an American hero robbed of his glory as one of Clint Eastwood's most exceptional efforts from the last decade.

title: Richard Jewell
review: The story Eastwood is telling here is indeed a compelling one, a real-life drama recounting the abuse of power by the two most powerful institutions in America, the government and the press.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Richard Jewell does well to tell a little-known story and is probably the best dramatisation of these events that there can be.

title: Richard Jewell
review: It's a sloppily made, slapdash affair that coasts entirely on a handful of excellent performances and the goodwill afforded to it by its intended audience.

title: Richard Jewell
review: The indefatigable Eastwood's latest turn in the director's chair tackles the real life story of 1990s security guard Richard Jewell in a biopic with strong playing alongside a few controversial decisions and queasy touches.

title: Greenlight
review: At 83 minutes, Greenlight is slower in parts than a thriller/horror should be and should never give you time to think, but it's a taut ride with some crazy fun shots.

title: Greenlight
review: A horror tale a little too good to be a "film festival only" movie, a little too promising to appreciate on its own pedestrian terms.

title: Greenlight
review: An interesting spin on the Hollywood machine, Greenlight is an enjoyable exploration of the lengths some people will go to to achieve their dreams.

title: Greenlight
review: While it's not perfect and the pacing is a bit muddled, Greenlight really nails the relationship between the young upstart director and the world-weary producer.

title: Greenlight
review: Greenlight is a tight thriller with some thrilling twists and you should catch it before it blows up big.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing He Wanted seems so taken with its own intricacy that it manages only to trip itself up.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: What makes The Last Thing He Wanted ultimately so frustrating (while also elevating it a few notches above its awfulness as a thriller) is the fact that there are things it does quite well.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: How does a director as stellar as Dee Rees go so thunderously wrong adapting a 1996 novel by the great Joan Didion, with a cast headed by Anne Hathaway, Ben Affleck, and Willem Dafoe? Here's Exhibit A and the last thing any of us wanted.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: I found the whole narrative confusing. Even if you can parse it out, it doesn't add up to a whole lot.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: There's some overreach and muddle here - you wouldn't want a pop quiz on the plot - but "Last Thing" remains an intriguing, visually diverting piece, well shot by Bobby Bukowski.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The big problem with the movie isn't the muddle, but the strain.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: A convoluted and incoherent political thriller meant to get lost in Netflix's vast catalogue. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: Not even Anne Hathaway can save this one.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: [Anne Hathaway] never becomes an interesting character... Willem Dafoe can't save the disaster either. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing has the pizzazz and the cinematic bravado necessary for a taut political thriller, but the film falls flat from the outset.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: Nothing works properly and with genuine conviction in The Last Thing He Wanted. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing He Wanted is a political thriller so incoherent, disjointed, convoluted, and boring that its very existence proves to be perplexing.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Its pure beating heart and humanistic undertones make it somewhat of a standout.

title: All the Bright Places
review: A refreshingly sober spin on YA romance.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Elle Fanning and Justice Smith are gorgeous together and have lovely chemistry.

title: All the Bright Places
review: There's messaging inserted near the start of the end credits for those who might be affected by the themes raised. But it doesn't negate what comes before it: a film that lingers briefly in the deep end but remains disappointingly shallow.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Though it's not without humor, "All the Bright Places" takes teens' emotions seriously and will move romantics of any age - in possibly unexpected ways.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Smith and Fanning bring thoughtful performances to this delicate tale.

title: All the Bright Places
review: While [All the Bright Places] remains sensitive towards its heavy themes of mental-illness and suicide, it also ends up being a little problematic in it's road to closure.

title: All the Bright Places
review: 'All the Bright Places' impressed me with its honesty, compassion, and sensitive performances by Elle Fanning and Justice Smith, who project amazing chemistry together on screen.

title: All the Bright Places
review: In a world full of inexplicable book-to-film adaptations, All the Bright Places is a diamond in the rough.

title: All the Bright Places
review: It also shows people of all ages that this too shall pass, that humans are resilient but also fragile, and life will continuously surprise you. I think that All The Bright Places is a beautiful film. You will probably cry, but it will be worth it.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Charming, sweet, and often deeply gripping and emotional, All the Bright Places is a mesmerizing coming-of-age story told with immense skill.

title: All the Bright Places
review: [T]here is an undeniable warmth and tenderness to Fanning and Smith's performances that makes this a worthy, if not particularly memorable, addition to a thriving sub-genre.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: There were some very high highs and some very low lows...the 49-minute special is a pretty wild ride. Like, yes, I was chuckling almost the whole time, but there were low points, friends...

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: Davidson runs thin on material, especially when you cut out extended, poorly paced anecdotes about fellow celebrities.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: The cycle begins anew. Alive From New York is designed to trigger a modest but manageable backlash. Whatever happens from here-good, bad, or ugly-you can bet Davidson will at least get some material out of it.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: This performance is so raw, director Jason Orley leaves in not just the parts Davidson says he'd cut from the special, but also the aside the comic makes to him from onstage about a joke he wants left in, too.
